Finally completed this game, and so I've decided to give my thoughts on it finally to review it. This is ALL based on the core campaign. I have not tried Be the Zombie, and I do not have the other paid dlc.  Techland, if you remember, also made Dead Island. I tried Dead Island. I did not like it. I found the game's premise and execution silly, unimmersive and that it could not decide whether or not it wanted to be an action, a comedy or a horror game, and as a result ended up being not a single one. It became a bland amalgam of kicking infinitely with the occasional weapon thrown at zombies. It felt incomplete, it felt rushed, it felt pretty awful. NPC interactions were Skyrim/Fallout 3 level of stilted and creepy, and nothing felt natural whatsoever. The decision to avoid the question of kids entirely was not only cowardly but also terribly executed, meaning that we heard about kids in the setting, but never saw them, interacted with them, saw what could have happened. That coupled with the crippling bugs Dead Island had meant that it was in no way fun, engaging, or enjoyable for me. you can only have weapons just spontaneously vanish from your inventory a very few times before you want to throw the whole ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ game out of a window.  So when Dying Light came out, I was understandably skeptical.  I was wrong to be. Dying Light is everything Dead Island wanted to be, and even more. You can see the lessons they've learned from Dead Island in Dying Light. Its tightly coded, it runs really well (albeit very hot on my GTX 760, seriously that thing makes the card race like crazy and I'm not on high details either. Within tolerances obviously, but it makes me nervous), kicks are now balanced and not the free superweapon it was in Dead Island, the parkour is a new addition but is exceptionally well done, the sidequests and survivor events are natural and feel great, the npcs feel like actual people, and interactions with them in cutscenes and ingame dialogue are natural, weapon-play and gunplay are great fun and the few guns in the game are very well balanced, there's several lovely little comedy bits in the game to break up the rather grim storyline, and cute little easter eggs here and there as well...  As for the story, it's incredible. Government conspiracy, weapons research, a mysterious plague and less than ethical people with their own agendas running around with you stuck smack dab in the middle... a morally grey character to begin with yourself. Yes unfortunately Crane is Yet Another Straight White Male Hero, but please look past that, it's a great game and a great story regardless.  Unfortunately even Dying Light has its downsides. There's very, VERY few bugs that interrupt and cause serious problems with the gameplay. The few bugs that do exist are actually pretty hilarious (some physglitching of ragdolls and at one point I found myself able to very very easily parkour THROUGH the ceiling of an area, I screenshotted it :) ), so that's not a huge problem. However what lets the game down significantly is the final confrontation with the central antagonist of the game.  There's a lot of really excellent, really tense parkour and combat segments leading up to getting to the guy, and it's super immersive. Despite there being no timer on the screen or even mechanically in game for it, you still have a very real sense of there being a real rush to get to them before they escape, and there's some amazing pieces, where it's all under your control, and at no point do you get interrupted by a cutscene in your massive obstacle course you have to navigate.  Unnntil you get face to face with the guy. And then what do they do? It's a rather pathetically simple QTE. Here's the solution. Press S. Press D. Press W. Press A. Press S again. Hammer F. Hammer F again. Done.   That's it. That is quite literally how to win the final confrontation. It all plays out through an 'interactive cutscene' where ♥♥♥♥ing up = instant death. Mercifully it is a short segment and you don't find yourself running that whole course again, but it REALLY, REALLY takes you out of the game and after all that, you have all control and agency taken away from you as a player. YOU don't get to kill the badguy through anything but a QTE. The game 'rewards' you for doing its godawful boring QTE by killing the badguy for you in a cutscene. If you'd gotten control of a weapon or something and had to aim and pull the trigger yourself, that'd be great! If you had to work through a puzzle to stop him getting away, that'd be perfect! You'd actually FEEL like YOU beat the badguy instead of the game doing it for you as a 'reward' for completing the simplest game of Simon! to ever exist.  I was on the edge of my seat, quite literally, up until the final confrontation and hte moment I saw those button presses came up all enjoyment was just sapped away. It was pretty heartbreaking to be honest, but now that I've slept on it, I realise that Dying Light is STILL a fantastic, wonderful game, and I am VERY tempted to start the game right from the beginning again and try to get all the notes and voicemails so I can see the ENTIRETY of the story, piecing it together from little clues.  Rambling done, here's the verdict:  Story: Top notch, no complaints whatsoever, it's fantastic. It knows just when to be serious and when to lighten the mood with comedy. Characters FEEL real and natural and you get to really like a lot of them, even badguys. You even get to see your own character's growth through the story, as he goes from helping people for purely mercantile reasons to actually giving a ♥♥♥♥ for the poor people in Harran.  Graphics: Really really pretty. There is some awful textures in the game, which is a terrible shame, but in general the world is laid out really nicely and even with your 'view distance' whacked down to minimal, there is no 'pop-in' of important things like obstacles or enemies, so even on a low end rig you never find yourself running head first into a zombie that just appeared in front of you on an otherwise clear straight road. It can strain lower end graphics cards but it's still very nicely optimised. I get a solid framerate on low-medium graphics with my GTX 760 and it's a very enjoyable experience.  Difficulty: Just right. Even at the end with a max levelled character and some way OP weapons I crafted myself, large groups of infected are still a risky proposition, and the night dwelling abominations are still legitimately terrifying without being horribly overpowered and unfair. Whilst guns do attract the infected, they are still viable in certain situations and still fun to use as well, and you really do have to weigh the risk of firing the guns over their lethality. It's all very nicely balanced.  Gameplay: Really really top notch all the way up until the end where it falls short, forcing you through a QTE cutscene for the final confrontation. Up until then, the parkour is fluid and natural and easy to understand, and rapidly becomes muscle memory even after not playing it for ages, and it really does work in FPS too, much better than Mirror's Edge ever managed. Granted there's not a lot of wall running (it's a little difficult to pull off but it can be done I think), but thankfully there doesn't need to be. The grappling hook does make certain segments way easier than they should be but even that's wonderfully balanced. You got maybe 2 to 3 shots of it before you wear it out and it needs to recharge... which can get you killed if you over use it, though similarly if you are careful it can save you from a VERY nasty fall...  Overall: I'd rate this pretty highly, let down only by a godawful boring QTE cutscene for a final boss, but everything else about the game is fantastic. Numbers are meaningless but if you must have them, I'd say Dying Light gets an 8.8/10 government conspiracies. All is forgiven for Dead Island, Techland; just work on the climaxes!

After becoming an independent publisher, Techland's newest zombie survival game, and successor to their Dead Island franchise (now owned by Deep Silver) blows me out of the water, and is stunning both visually and mechanically. The parkour system makes a somewhat stale genre much more exciting. It adds flavor to the stale combat most games boast, and this game makes full use of it. After completing the main story singleplayer, I can say that it's one of my favorite games, and one I hope to get the DLC for.   Pros: -Amazing graphics -Parkour is insanely fun, well designed and useful -Gameplay feels nice -Inventory and collecting loot feels nice and is well designed -nice skill tree that feels good and leveling up is at a good pace -Nice variety of special infected -Steam Workshop and Custom content -Co-op (I haven't even touched it yet) -Nice story  Cons: -Gameplay may eventually feel repetetive -Normal zombies somewhat weak (could be a good thing) -I often find I don't have to fight most of the special infected due to parkour (see next paragraph) -Not many players in Be the Zombie mode (since I last played) -I didn't find myself needing to roam around much at night (thought that may just be me)  This game is amazing. It's graphics could definitely be the best for a fps game as of the time of this review, and it's new parkour mechanic is refreshing, and has even led me to search for more games like this (tried mirror's edge, but this game made it's somewhat dated parkour system and graphics feel lacking and less fluid). I often find that I run rather than fight (my personal playstyle in this game), leading me to take full advantage of the parkour system. The combat system on the other hand is still good, but it's similar to existing combat mechanics, and along with most games, it could get repetitive.  I felt the story was good, but others have argued that the Dead Island games had better, more compelling stories. The main story took me around 23 hours to complete, and there are plenty of side quests and challenges left for me to complete. In addition to those, there are custom maps and content via the Steam Workshop, many of which are very good and can easily double one's playtime (with time and an already growing community, and more importantly mapmakers of course). Overall, you will get your money's worth of playtime from this game.  The upcoming Following DLC set to release in February of 2016 looks great so far and includes improvements to the base game, both visually and mechanically. It also adds cars, but is set in 'the country,' a less populated rural area, with open fields and more dangerous enemies. While the addition of cars (and highly customizable ones at that) and a more open area, I fear that parkour will be less utilized, thought that has yet to be seen.  Sorry, if this review looked like a rant, but overall, I would rate this game a 9/10

You play as Super American who drops into Sandplace. Sandplace is infested by zombies. Oh gee, I wonder where they came from? Who cares? There's a doctor who has some kind of medicine that delays infection. So?  The story is uninspired and, frankly, boring. Same goes for jumping and climbing puzzles, that are littered everywhere, especially in side quests. When people ask you to help, there is little motivation to actually do so. Run across half the map for 25 minutes to get some XP and a semi-rare wrench? No thank you! Just roam the city, kill ♥♥♥♥ and loot.  I recommend Dying Light once the price tag goes down. Wait for a sale and have fun, play with a friend in co-op mode. Expect good gameplay, but little else.

I love zombie themed games and this is basically FarCry 3 with Zombies (seriously I'm convinced the devs from Dying Light used the same engine as there were features that I've absolutely seen in both games). This game is surprisingly good, I recommend it if youre looking for a new coop game to play with friends or just a nice open world game mixed with parkour.    Story (6/10):   While nothing special it does have its set of memorable characters. The main cast is pretty average and forgettable but the characters in the side quests are hilariously whacky and memorable.    Graphics (8/10):   The game is absolutely beautiful and has flawless triple monitor support. You can see ripples on the clothing, grass and trees moving in the wind which only gets better during raining and storming weather. The facial animations on non story critical characters are a little stiff but the animations are pretty good otherwise.     Gameplay (8/10):   The gameplay is pretty good and the parkour is pretty smooth, it may be no mirrors edge but it still boasts a lot of similar parkour. The melee combat is where the game shines with upgradable melee weapons that degrade over time, you can get perks to help make your weapons last longer but even at higher level youre still watching your melee weapon usage. The gun play is pretty good and im disappointed the guns dont wear down Far Cry 2 style but it balances out since melee weapons do more damage.  The night time can be absolutely terrifying right up until higher levels, my first experience with night time was an adrenaline rush even in coop.  The game will feel very familiar to those who've played Mirror's Edge and as a fan of Mirror's Edge, i can easily recommend this game for those looking for a new parkour game.    Controls:   I'm not giving a score on this since I played it on both PC and Xbox 360 controller controls, so I'll write a mini review for it.  The PC controls are pretty good but the mouse sensivity takes time to get used to (i really cant explain this problem) but it still feels very natural compared to most multiplatform titles. The Xbox 360 controlers however, are clunky and take a lot of time getting used to but still very playable ones used to it.    Coop (8/10):   The coop is pretty damn good, its peer2peer and you join the client's game and you do their quests and story. Its drop in and drop out so you can leave and join anytime. The 'Be The Zombie' gamemode is similar to the Dark Souls invasion and can make even the most battle hardened survivors work together. I really recommend this game if youre tired of all the current coop zombie games like CoD zombies, Left 4 Dead 2 and Killing Floor.    Technical Info:   This game isnt quite optimized for PC and my first 5-10 hours involved me having a problem where the cutscenes would run at 15fps despite pulling 40fps in triple screen resolution (5760x1080) and apparently its coming problem but looks like its fixed now (it happened to different people no matter the resolution or setup).  The game has flawless triple monitor support and the side screens darken when entering cinematics. I recommend keeping 'View Distance' at the default or turning it down because it has a major performance impact for little effect (it just makes foliage more visible in the distance, thats it).  Apparently this game has very very basic Oculus Rift support but I havent tested it until they get something worth testing.

When I first saw Dying Light on Steam I was suspicious that it would be a Dead Island clone, and I was not entirely wrong since the gameplay, crafting and the special zombies are really similar.  The thing that makes Dying Light better is the survival aspect and the difficulty you will experience in the first half of the game and during the nights when the super zombies from hell roam the streets seeking to eat you.  I have never played a game that immersed me so much in a Zombie apocalypse like this one : the zombies are really numerous, dangerous and attracted by noise, there are numerous encounters with survivors fighting zombies, selling stuff or just resting on roofs, supplies are frequently airdropped on the map containing medkits, emergency packages and flares (useful during the night) and you have to hurry to get them or the bandits will be there to take it.  I should also point out that the firearms are really more powerful and easy to use than in Dead Island, for instance a single bullet to the head with any gun will OS most of the zombies and humans you will encounter making them really useful during the day (during the night shooting will draw all the volatile's attention).  The only thing that bothered me was the story, interesting in the beginning and then really lame the more you progress in the campaign, which is quite short to be honest. On the bright side the optional quests are fun to do and compensate for the short campaign.  Runs well between 50-60 fps on my pc at almost max settings. -Nvidia Geforce GTX 770 -intel i5 2500K -12 GB RAM  Edit : Apparently the game doesn't run well on AMD yet.

TL;DR: Best Zombie Combat Game in a Long Time, Cliche Story. They are Releasing Mod Tools And fixing Problems. Buy the Game. Perfect Example of How A poor story prevents GOTY.    ^^^ Keep an eye on Hours Played ^^^  Edit: Beat the Main story and 90% of the Side Quests in 40hrs. (66%) I'll get 100% compleation and see what happens.   The moment you see it cross 61 hours, sell your Kid's toys and buy the game. For every game I play I employ a simple method to see if the game was worth it or not: For every Dollar I spend, I expect an equal amount of gameplay hours. In this case, I spent 60 (not including the aditional 60 for my friend's copy) So I expect 60 hours of gameplay. While this may seem unfair let me point towards a few games like Skyrim ($60 -> 551 Hours), Terraria ($10 -> 368 Hours), Torchlight 2 ($20 -> 97 Hours), and even an incomplete game like Starbound ($15 -> 79 Hours) By using this I like to give games a percentage from 0% (having never played at all) to x% (seeing as The more I play a game the higher percentage)   At the Time of this Review Dying Light is at 46% (not including if I pick up the Season Pass)  Normally I would just say a resounding 'No' to anything under 50%, however It will easially break 50% as my friend and I continue to play.   Just to Clarify  0% - 50% Resounding 'No' 51% - 75% Grab it on Sale 76% - 100% Pick It up if you have some Spare Cash 100+% - Sell your children and buy the game. (Like Skyrim at 330%)  Keep In mind this is more of a system to figure out if it was really worth the money. The system isn't designed to include pure entertainment value (For example this scale doesn't really work for seeing the Grand Canyon or a Show on broadway if you like that sort of thing) You can also adjust it with diferent ratios such as 2 hours per Dollar or vice versa since 22hrs may be more than enough for some people. Anyway on to the actual review.   Gameplay:  Gameplay is the single most important thing in well. Games. It's all fine and good if you enjoy a story, but if getting from story point A to story point B is hell-and-a-half then there's no way I'm spending more than a hour playing. So far Dying Light has Impressed me with incredibly satisfying combat and movement. I need to talk about them together because without eachother we'd just be playing Mirrors Edge: Harran or Dead Island. Also note that while there isn't a direct difficulty, it seems to scale with how far you progress in the game. As we play I notice more scary zombies and the biters grab more (also more in quantity). While I like the way this is done, I feel like there isn't much incentive to play though again on 'Hardcore' mode. since it doesn't exist.     Leaping off a roof and drop kicking zombies off cliffs   Throwing a dagger at an Air Canister on the back of zombies and watching it ragdoll down the street (or right towards you) then it promptly exploding in a crescendo of red mist.    Recieving a reward for saving a survivor then watching him get jumped by 30 more zombies because he was too stupid to use the rooftops.    You and your buddy leaping to the rescue of a survior being attack by thugs (promptly knocking him off his feet) and Kicking him to death like some sort of gang initiation gone wrong, only to dissapear into the sunset like a Post-apocolyptic Batman and... Batman (no one wants to be Robin)   Realizing 'Biters' (Slow and Stupid Day zombies) Don't know how to climb down things without falling over, then promptly leading them to the edge of cliffs. I mean really, they even trip over eachother.    Filling our pants with execess weight during night missions (no really I hate-in-a-good-way the night in this game)    Laughing at the Noises the Hazmat Zombie makes. heheh toilet humor.    Anyway I could keep going. Everything (including Guns) feels incredibly Satisfying to use, zombies are fun to kill and the movement system (minus a few hiccups) is for the most part fluid and feels like you're free running.   Story:  Eh, pretty typical Zombie stuff here. Sidequests have garnered more than a chuckle from time to time.   Co-op:   See this one is important to me. I Love co-op games and honestly I think this does it in the perfect way (much like borderlands does) The Story isn't geared towards 'there's more than one of you' it's exactly the same for both of us, We're just experiencing it together. There are some minor issues with animations and I wish there were more things we could do as far as 'special zombie executing move 9000' but that's okay. The important thing everything works without much issus. Techland could go incredibly far with this, lets hope they have the sense too.   Im sick of writing this. I'll do that + and - thing everyone else did now.  +Satisfying melee and Gun combat +Wonderful movemt System +♥♥♥♥-your-pants tense night cycle +Decently Interesting Crafting System +Level as you use it Skill/Level system +Skill trees where everything is pretty useful +Lots of loot and secrets to find +Rewards Exploration +Co-op that works the first time  -Meh Story -No Moding tools -No Difficulty choices (Easy/Med/Hard) -Not enough varity of zombies (they have crazy ones, get crazier, Maybe in Expansions)    All in all it's a great game. I want it to pass my Hr/$ test. I also want them to release dev tools and say screw multiplayer (verses not co-op) I want mods. If they work on building up a Skyrim like modding community then Dying Light will be around a very long time.

This game is like Dead Island - Only, it's actually good, This game is like Mirrors Edge - Only, it's actually good.  Although I am not usually a fan of the First Person perspective, this game is just done right. The immersion is fabulous.  Combat just feels right, one or two zombies, no problem. Mob of 5? Pushing it a little but manageable unless you find yourself cornered or haven't planned an emergency escape route. Once you get the hang of it though Zombie killing becomes second nature. Darting through even large mobs, quickly kicking one out of your way and smashing anothers skull with your wrench just to let them know you mean buisness. The special zombies in the game also add a nice variety and more of a challange too, especially if they have a bit of a mob with them. Loud noises also attract 'Virals', Zombies on steriods, suddenly that gas bottle you just used to blow up an entire mob doesn't seem like it was such a good idea, it's best to leave the area asap or prepare for a really rough fight.  However as storylines such as the 'Walking Dead' have warned us, it may not be the dead that pose the biggest threat in an apocolypse... its other Humans.  In an open world with limited supplies its no surprise bandits are rife, a bit harder to deal with than mushy headed dead walkers. Usually out numbered the threat already feels very real, and of course with working brains and quicker reflexes they are able to evade and dodge. Taking on these guys is a frantic mele battle where reactions are essential and wits are put to the test. Take them head on or plan a more complex strategy? the open world makes the choice yours.  Then just when you think you might have got the hang of it, it gets dark. Warned in advance of the approaching gloom via your watch or your radio, you better hope you've cleared out a safe house or there's some live traps nearby because things are about to get real. Turn on your torch and attract everything nearby or stumble through the darkness hoping to stay out of sight. Virals roam freely at night, with thier cone of vision visable on your map its possible to avoid them with careful espionage-like gameplay. Get seen however and you better start running. With double XP during the night it can be fruitful to stay out past dark, providing of course you can actually evade the nighmares chasing you. Urgency and panic create a further immersion that many other survival games just don't pull off. I have yet to be invaded by another real player, though I imagine its terrifying.  The three skills trees gain XP independently and offer various paths to suit your style of gameplay. The crafting system is also fairly indepth. Modify your base weapons with elemental damage by finding weapon blueprints and crafting materials. You can also create throwables, medkits and lockpicks.  So far having a great deal of fun, worth a play for any survival/zombie fan.   I have not yet tried the Multiplayer Co-op or 'Be the Zombie', however I already feel this was worth the preorder.

Dying Light is fantastic. I'm on my second playthrough of the vanilla game and just into the new content and it's easily one of my favorite games in the last few years. If it had a weak point I think it'd be the story and sometimes how it's presented, and I found the story's ending a little bit...dissatisfying. But EVERYTHING else about it is nonstop fun. Parkouring across the city or country from building to building, running and jumping and grappling is so much fun the game could just be that and I think I'd love it, but then you have awesome fighting mechanics that make the decapitation, dismemberment and immolation of enemies so fun you'll giggle like a maniac.   Now with the Following, they've given us cars that we can customize and run over zombies with. I'm cooping with my SO and his brother and it is seriously one of my favorite things we've ever played. The melee weapons are fantastic and the DLC has brought us way better guns (though I still love slashing things with machetes, personally). I love the blueprints and collectables and exploring.   There's some times the game really gets my heart pounding too. Being chased by a healthy grouping of Volatiles at night and you accidentally have molotovs keyed up instead of the grappling hook? Or there's just nowhere to run? Better pray you have a backup plan. There's some genuinely creepy and disturbing parts too.   Overall, it's a blast. It's a gory, drivey, parkoury blast.

TLDR Overall (9 out of 10 so far). If you liked Dead Island but wanted more grit, tension (man, the nights in this game), freedom in movement, variety in gameplay, satisfying combat and levelling, an actual penalty for death (and thus reason to want to stay alive) and exploration (a deeper thinking man's Parkour Dead Rising Island you could say) then this should definitely be for you. Its been 2 months since I stopped playing Dying Light. Having time to reflect on the experience I can say that it was very immersive and would say its the next level of games. I'm 33 and started playing at CounterStrike 1.6 so I've played more games then I'd like to admit. The story starts off with a creative entrence to the infected area, from there you learn different skills to taking down your adverseries and completing tasks or quests if you'd like to call them that. Some games the tasks seem very tedious but this game not so much. Any where you go the park core skills make your travels fun and enjoyable. The 1st half of the game I was grinding through leveling skills, doing side quests, and enjoyed every main story line there was. The park core element of the game made you feel like there were not map restrictions like with most games, you could climb go run anywhere you want, which ultimately helped you feel like you were immersed in a story and not playing a game. The 2nd half of the game introduced some new very exciting elements being in more of a urban london type feel setting, by then you should be a master at taking down your foes. Some of the quests you get sent on start to get a little tedious but they arn't to bad. Most of the leveling that affects your play style happens in the 1st half. On a scale of 1 to 10 rating the 1st 1/2 of the game id give it a 9/10, the second half I'd give a 5/10. The ending was perfect although bitter sweet and I wish the experience would continue. Looking back this is definitly a buy and I would recommend this as a first person shooter with fun and interesting story line. if you like zombie books like World War Z you will love this game.

This game is highly recommended in my list. The story is quite amazing and the details in graphics is simply astonishing. Preferably play the game with a controller as playing with keyboard and mouse presents some what more difficult.   Graphics: 9/10 gameplay: 8/10 Story/character development: 7/10 Violence/gore/explosions: 10/10  Pro's and cons:  + with side quests and main quest this game will keep you busy for quite some time (took me 28 hours to finish the game) + graphics will keep amazing you through out the entire game. + Mirrors edge, Assassins creed and dead island are smashed into one terrifying awesome game. + The custimization of weapons and progression of your skill tree is definetely noticed in survival and will make you want to try and level them up a.s.a.p, which is challenging. + there are challenges you can complete for extra xp in agility and power (or for money and modification blueprints) which of some are very challenging and rewarding. + The night time makes your heart pound and makes you sweat gallons as you try to evade the scariest zombies ever and will keep you on your toes. Also, rewards are doubled for surviving outside during the night, which is highly rewarding if you managed to do quests. + Kicking zombies of rooftops, stairs, bridges and other high area's is incredibly satisfying. + The story has moments where you get ♥♥♥♥♥♥ off, sad and laugh as the character does.  - There are some graphical bugs where you glitch through certain objects, which makes the experience a bit less real. - Your grappling hook is rather bugged and at times will attach to something invisible or will shoot you in the wrong direction. - You need to look at EACH ledge as you try to grab them, not looking at the ledge means: no grab = fall to you death and can cause quite the amount of rage now and then. - sometimes doesn't grab the ledge even when directly staring at it. (more rage material) - Once you reach higher level's and the weapons become increasingly strong, normal zombies are no longer scary as you cut them down with 1 maybe 2 cuts/hits of your weapons. - 'be the zombie' mode is currently broken and needs to be fixed.  Overall I give the game a 8/10 and highly recommend playing it. Despite the slight bugs here and there and the 'be the zombie mode' not working properly the game is insanely fun and the co-op mode is incredibly satisfying, especially when playing with friends.  Tl;DR:  Game is insanely fun, has amazing graphics, good story line and character development along with a satisfying co-op mode and despite some bugs here and there and a 'be the zombie' mode that still needs some adjusting the game is incredibly satisfying to play and would highly recommend purchasing it.

I went into Dying Light not knowing what to expect. At first, I thought the game was superb. The climbing and running, fighting were all great.  However halfway through the game, or even before that, the charm starts to wear off. I mean, its all still fun... but it got too easy. The enemies don't really get stronger, so eventually you become this god amongst men. I personally still found the game enjoyable even until the end, but I can see where some people would have issues with the way the game turned out.  Then there's the multiplayer, the coop was alright. You got to play everything you could alone, but with pals. Of course, this only compounded the whole issue with the game being easy, because I didn't see any kind of added difficulty when playing with other people.  There was also a versus, where 1 player controlled super zombie fought against up to 4 player controlled humans. I don't really know what to say about this. It was unbalanced. The matchmaking was terrible. But once again, I actually really liked playing as the hunter zombie. The main issue being how hard it was to actually find a match. I'm guessing there were many more zombie players looking for matches than vice versa. This ended up in 10+ minutes of refreshing and hoping you join a game before someone else steals the spot.  But I digress. Great game, few flaws. I got my moneys worth. 8/10

I loved DL. I really did. And I'd recommend this game to anyone. I'm not going to talk about what makes DL great, you either like it or you don't. I do want to spend a little time talking about some of the things I personally feel would have made DL a much better game;  Weapon Blueprints: Pretty restricting, especially at first. For about 10 hours (I spent a lot of time exploring/looting) The only things I could really mod at a rare level was knives. (I know the basic level mods could mostly be used on any melee weapon). I also disliked that it was possible to obtain duplicate blueprints.  Weapon Customisation: Pretty simple honestly. I do feel as though the system was about on par (If not a little worse) than Dead Island. There was nothing too special about it. Certainly didn't bring anything new. I feel the opportunity was certainly there to do more.  Ranged Weapon customization: Why isn't there any? The world was full of loot, something a little dayZ-esque would have been amazing. By this I mean, why not add different types/quality of gun components to be looted within the world. Foregrips, buttstocks, silencers, mags of varying sizes, different scopes. The ability to craft different ammo types. Anything that could alter the way your guns behaved to add more fun and variation to gun gameplay.  Skill Tree: Mostly pretty decent if not a little basic, but there was nothing for ranged weapons at all. Could definitely have added something. I don't like the fact that the option to pick up every single skill existed. More skills would have added a sense of choice, or at least the ability to enhance certain aspects of the way you play. More one hand skills, more two-hand skills, etc. This would have given a more in-depth choice to the player on the style they wanted to play.  Looting: Loads of loot in the game, but honestly once you're done you realise it's mostly pointless. I ended the game with a huge excess of random craft components that I had no use for at all. I partly feel that several issues are to blame for that. (Lack of gun customisation, pretty average and lazy weapon modding/customisation etc). You're far better off looting for what you need. Looting for the sake of looting is pointless.  Game balance: Honestly a little weird. Once as I bought myself a decent legendary quality weapon, threw in three mods and crafted it into a rare level (Or higher) elemental weapon, the toughest infected in the game died in two hits. It stayed this way for a great deal of level ups, so I only really crafted new weapons with higher damage for the sake of owning a weapon with bigger numbers. I didn't need it. It also made two-hands a little pointless save for the unique techniques you learned for them. Which weren't really needed because again, two attacks and dead.  Optimisation was, at times, pretty horrible (By now everyone knows this). I run an I75820k and two GTX980's with 16gb DDR4 OC'd at 3666hz. Spitter bombs actually crashed my game at least half a dozen times, if it didn't crash It would slow down to a crawl for a few seconds.  Great game though, i thoroughly enjoyed DL (Mostly because of my love for Zombie games!). But it was honestly good fun. Some epic moments, some epic side quests. Story was really good, wish there was more of it. I might seem harsh on the game but it's only because while I loved it, I believe there could have been *so* much more.

Seamlessly blending survival, action, horror, exploration, story-driven progression, and RPG elements - Dying Light is a game that has the potential to make you feel like a kid again. I'm about halfway through the story, I've experienced luring dumb zombies into traps by day and running from insanely fast and agile terrors by night. This game feels like several different types of games/genres which are flawlessly blended to create an immersive experience unparalleled.  I could not stand Dead Island, which was made by the same company. Dying Light makes Dead Island look like they were either trolling people, or weren't sure what type of game they wanted to make at the very least.  I never looked forward to this game, didn't know anything about it. I got the demo because I could. Played it, and was immediately blown away. Bought the game on sale and never regretted it. I'm about 63 hours in so far and only '53%' through the main story. Also, and I won't mention this much because the gameplay is so solid, but the graphics are insane and very impressive.  Since I've owned it now they have released an enhanced edition (for free) which adds 'new levels' more or less and other enhancements. Just as I thought the game was getting a little easy, (keep in mind there is a learning curve which I have really mastered with the Steam Controller which makes me feel like somewhat of a badass), the next town over provided a sobering challenge that left me frantically fighting to survive at times like I was brand new at the game. I also enabled the new Nightmare mode which made even the weakest zombies a real challenge.  I have not even made it as far as The Following yet (the massive expansion) and I really look forward to it. This game continues to be fun as hell and blow me away. Every positive review you see is there for a reason. Get the demo if you have doubts, and get the game otherwise. It's even more fun with friends, and I've played most of the game solo and STILL had a roller coaster of a good time.  It's first person, parkour (free-running), zombie, action, stealth, rpg, open world, day/night cycle, exploratory fun. Other than that, it's hard to describe exactly how immersive it is. You should have already played this by now. The day/night cycle adds a great deal of depth and immersion, and if you're caught outside goofing around at daytime and scavenging as night descends and you're unprepared, the entire game turns upside down as you desperately scramble and fight for your life to make it to the nearest safehouse. Or you play it smart and lucky and sneak around, hoping and praying you don't make too much noise.  Just play it already, even if it's the demo. GIve it a shot. It's too much fun not to try.  Edit: Wifey reminded me to mention that they released a companion app for Android / iOS where you can manage sending squads into the city to loot and rescue survivors and such. It's a fun side-mission companion app that allows you to send items aquired to your character in the PC game to use. I've never seen this level of interactivity in a game before, and I rarely see this kind of dedication (overall) from developers. Techland, effing bravo.

This is a review based on the first 2 hours of gameplay - played through the entire initial prologue (fairly extensive and lengthy). Coming from an FPS veteran who cut his teeth on Wolfenstein 3D and has played almost every FPS since, I can unreservedly recommend this. If you enjoyed Dead Island, this is a very similar, albeit FAR superior game. This doesn't have nearly the same comic-book feel to it, and the graphics are impressive.  Pros:   Free-running/parkour - this is done very well - not frustrating and clunky like Assassin's Creed, and it's also not a 'can't miss' QTE either. You're not a superhuman, and it IS possible to miss ledges/grabs/balances - however, this is largely due to player skill, not any form of bug. The free-running/mantling aspect is handled fluidly, and lends a sense that your body actually has some weight to it - it takes some skill, it's not just a matter of 'look at the grapple point, press a button, automatically teleport there with an animation'. Very life-like.  Graphics - high resolution, well put together. Not quite on the level of the new Frostbite engine, but very good - no complaints here.  Gameplay - if you liked Dead Island, you'll like this. Very similar. Crafting weapons, primarily melee-based, gather supplies/blueprints, special Giant Zombies etc.. Like another reviewer mentioned, the difference here is they focus more on the horde-mechanic, as opposed to a lot of individual encounters. Thus far, they definitely incentivize the free-running, think smart aspect as opposed to blithely wading into an encounter with your trusty rusty pipe.  Cons - The buildings and locales are all very similar. This could be because I'm primarily still in the early portion of the game, however I did enough side-exploring to see what the city offered. Not a lot of variants that I could see - mostly a favela-looking jungle of shanties. Not necessarily a bad thing, but also won't blow you away with variety.   9/10 - Simply put, if you liked Dead Island and want something slightly less comic-bookish, this is the game for you. It's basically Dead Island with free-running, but much, much better put together and less clumsy.

After just completing the story I recommend this game for many reasons but here are a few. First off is the parkour, it is a very sort of playground type parkour with a good skill tree to further enhance your fun such as dropkicks, rolls, and the good ole shoulder bash from Sam B himself. Melee combat in Dying Light has been revamped since their release of Dead Island. A whole new physics remake makes it feel satisfying when you get that hit on a zombie that pops the skull. However, if your fighting humans the melee system can be a lot trickier. They can block your attacks often (sometimes even throwables!) they can dodge kick etc. Now onto my favorite part, the story of this game. I will be sure to include no spoilers as I have just completed the game. It is a very well done story that can keep you captivated. I often found myself being drawn to story missions rather then as something I had to do to progress. The people you meet, tasks done are interesting and overall fun. There are even some humorous spots around. Now the heart and soul of Dying Light, the zombies. No one is quite sure where it came from but some interesting side quests do have theories. Dying Light got their zombies right the first time you see a new zombie it should really make you jump. Take the volatiles for example my first glance at one scared me real bad. Like heart pounding. I was terrified to be out at night alone. Eventually I had to and I was still scared. The zombies can be quite entertaining during the day however, watching them flop around. But just remember this game is entitled Dying Light. Which brings me whimpering to the next topic, coop. Coop is a fun thing to me, I have and always will love coop in free roam games. Coop can be used as a therapy for fear. Grab a couple of buddies and from a raiding group to travel at night. Raiding not your thing? Try challenges to add to the mix to keep the competition up. When you've experienced the fear from first seeing a zombie that is probably gonna make you scream and cry.Repeatedly. Coop will help you overcome that fear. Dying Light for me is a fun game, it can keep you entertained with it's rapid parkour and combat while keeping you intertwined with the story and many fun side quests which includes fetching coffee, crayons, and even gathering stuff at night. Don't forget Jeff's crazy idea 'The Apocalypse Wall.' I like Dying Light it brings to light some new and interesting mechanics (see what i did there) and a great storyline. Definitely worth a try to pick up and play if you get the chance.

Definitely lived up to the hype. Smooth as silk day 1. This game is awesome! The parkour aspect of movement is exciting and seamless. I've never played a game where melee combat felt this fluid and immersive. It's been a long time since I've physically ducked at things coming at me on screen.

What an awesome game Dying Light is.   Note: Haven't played The Following yet.   Dying Light takes place in a fictional place called Harran with there being two areas, the Slums and Oldtown/Sector 0. You play as Kyle Crane, voiced by the wonderful Roger Craig Smith (also does the voice for Sonic). Crane is a GRE operative sent to Harran the investigate the situation there and find a man named Rais. Now that we've got that, it's time for the pros and cons of Dying Light (in my opinion):   Positives: - The parkour elements are very well executed and work great in the enviroment. You can climb up almost everything. - The areas you play through are immersive, detailed, and, like I said, nearly everything can be climbed up or on. - The melee combat is incredibly satisfying and smooth. - There are lots of items that can be picked up and can be crafted into something else. - There are lot of side quests to keep you busy all throughout the game. - All of the skills on the skill tree don't feel useless and the leveling up in general is very well-done. - The game performs pretty well and has a decent amount of graphics options (including an FOV slider). - Most of the special enemies are cool looking and challenging to fight. - Playing through the night is a very interesting gameplay mechanic because the enemies get tougher and very difficult to kill enemies come out. Surviving a night rewards you with a huge XP bonus. - The finale of the game is very fun.   Negatives: - Although the story isn't that bad, it's still kind of lackluster with not many characters getting any attributes or traits associated with them. - The game does perform well but there are some random drops in performance in certain parts of the base game areas. - The gunplay doesn't feel right and it isn't very fun to use guns. - SPOILERS FOR THE END OF THE GAME:  The ending of the game is unsatisfying due to the QTE sequence that's used to kill Rais. It would've been more fulfilling if we were actually able to fight him.     Nonetheless, Dying Light is an incredible game if you're a fan of the survival horror/zombie game genre. I strongly recommend the game to anyone who likes zombie games or Mirror's Edge as the parkour in Dying Light feels on-par with it.

The Parkour: Really gives you that freedom of movement. The game is in first-person, and therefor there are no need for any player animations, which allows for much more diversed movement. Assassin's Creed is way too squared, as you can only jump/climb in eight different directions around you, and the parkour is very controlled by the game. You don't do much yourself, other than pushing some buttons. In Dying Light, on the other hand, you are moving freely around everywhere, so you have to watch your step. It's brutal and unforgiving, and that's what makes it so exciting. You never get bored of it!  The combat is pretty straight-forward when it comes to swinging your weapons, but you do have a lot of awesome body-attacks like jump-kicks and dodges and the like that are real fun to use, as well as effective. It does make the combat a bit tactic. You make a wrong move, you end up getting caught under a pile of zombies. The weapons are really creative, awesome and MANY. Looting is something you'll need to do constantly because you need items for repairing your worn weapons, and to create different things like molotovs and medkits. But that's okay, because the looting is pretty fast, and so is the lockpicking.  The enemies are frightening at first, but as you progress, they become easier to defeat, which gives you that awesome 'I-was-afraid-of-you-before-but-now-I-kill-you'-feeling. And yet even after that, you still keep a certain level of fear for your enemies because you want to fight as little as possible so you can conserve your supplies and weapons for when you really need them. This game is, as I said already, brutal and unforgiving; the more you do, the more skillpoints you earn, but you also lose a lot of skillpoints almost every time you die. That is one thing that actually makes you afraid of dying in this game, and that is great.  The story is maybe a bit far-fetched. It's not as simple as just surviving the zombie apocalypse. Apparently this story involves trying to find the cure, and resisting the government who wants to exploit the virus to make the apocalypse even worse. Never the less, it is a very exciting story that gives you a feeling of importance. Animations and voice-actings are very good, and the characters have very strong characteristics. Especially the villain, of course.  All in all, I liked the game a lot. But like most other open-world games I've played, I don't really feel like exploring the world that much, as almost everything gets slightly repetitive. I'm mainly in it for the storyline. Despite enjoying the game, I had this really uncomfortable and scared feeling throughout the whole playtime of 19 hours that it took me to complete it. It was like 'Damn, I want to just get done with this story so I can stop playing this game', and I'm not really sure. Still, a great game.  Oh, and... DON'T. GO. OUT. AT. NIGHT.

Revising from my previous review. This is a rather qualified recommendation that may change when The Following is release.  TL;DR: An intriguing, occasionally-frustrating take on the zombie theme. Focusing on first-person parkour and melee combat, and transforming into a wonderfully tense stealth game at night. Plenty of collectibles, challenges and sidequests for the open-world enthusiasts. Some frustrations with the main story and certain gameplay elements keep this title from earning a solid recommendation (one of those times you wish Steam had more than a Yes/No). It's definitely worth trying out the demo.  GAMEPLAY: The melee combat feels a LOT like Techland's previous work in Dead Island, and is broken up by the occasional ranged battle. The parkour seems mostly inspired by Mirror's Edge, but with clumsier controls. When you're in the open world, they function well enough, but always seem to fall short when needed most. The game seems to like to hide instant-death Boomer-style exploding zombies right behind corners, often resulting in frustrating deaths that highlight some poor decisions in checkpoint placement. An end-game gauntlet that kicks you back to its start led to my earlier, angrier review and to a multi-month surrender of sort. The game also likes to take away your gear (grappling hook, health packs, weapons) right before throwing its hardest bosses at you. These attempts to increase tension often only result in needless frustration.  However, the game truly shines at night. By combining crippling darkness with Volatiles- a fast, durable, hard-hitting kind of super zombie- Techland manages to transform this brawler into a stealth game. While there are safe zones all across the map, you earn extra XP for spending the night wandering around in the darkness, and even more XP for evading these Volatiles completely from dusk to dawn. These are my favorite parts of the game.  Also, as mentioned, the game has plenty to offer for achievement hunters. Safe spots to unlock, collectibles to track down. Plenty of side missions and challenges will keep you busy stomping thru (or sneaking around) zombies. These kind of things are what really drove me to finally come back, beat the main story, and get back to open world stuff.  STORY: A fairly forgettable affair. You come in as some government agent invesigating a possible cure. There's a mouthy raider boss claiming to know secrets about the cause of the outbreak trying to leverage this against said goverment. Characters are mostly forgettable, and you never really delve into their backstories. Side quests are fairly generic. At least the voicework isn't too bad.  GRAPHICS: A fairly technically-impressive game. I can run it quite well on an FX-6300 and R9-380 4GB with 8GB of ram. Thankfully, the motion blur that mired Dead Island can be switched off, and the FOV can be adjusted to one's liking. The game's color palette is mostly drab, tho I suppose that's befitting of a zombie outbreak. Ragdoll and clothing physics on the zombies is done well, and if you're into gory melee combat, few do it better than Dying Light. Interiors also allow for a degree of destrucitibility, with bits of drywall and broken glass often flying about during the game's few gunfights. The lighting is, oddly enough, most impressive at night, where barrel fires and what few lights still work help outline the intense shadows and roving Volatiles.  SOUND: As mentioned, the voice work has been done fairly well, but effects are where it's at here. Cutting up zombies is as much an aural experience as it is a visual one. Guns give out satisfying reports with each carefully-placed shot. The ambient audio can be nice, but the sound can also mislead at times. You'll hear a distant horde cry out in response to some careless noise, but they may never actually show. I turn the music off most of the time, but it has a bit of an Asian flare and isn't awful - I just think turning it off makes the nights that much better.   In the end, we'll see how the buggy-focused Following DLC pans out. I may be able to give the game a little more favor then. Still, it's worth a try for the zombie-slayers out there.

[First Impressions] I'm honestly surprised my game hasn't crashed or stuttered to hell. WB's QA department has delivered once again.  This is the game I wish Dead Island had been. Combat is fluid and fun, and the zombies are incredibly realistic. I've heard zombies splatter to the ground who had tried chasing me off a roof, I've seen them mantle with their torsos onto the floor to climb a ledge (in very zombie-like fashion).  If you begin a fight, it's very likely most nearby zombies will begin homing in to your position, tightening like a noose around your location if you get carried away for too long kicking a zombie into some spikes on the wall.   [Second Impressions] The game's holding my interest well. The parkour never gets boring, though I've encountered a few hitches in areas with lots of climbable ledges too close together. The story so far has also steadily increased in intensity, and I find myself wondering where the plot will swing to next.   The skill trees are the highlight of my gaming experience right now. There's plenty of cool abilities to be unlocked, and pretty much all the individual skills are useful.   I also saw some other reviews complaining about the day/night cycle. It really all depends on where you are in the game. I spent the longest time exploring during the prelude to a story mission, because the game was simulating the day/night in real time, regardless of where I was on the map. It seems like most of the time the in-game hours are clucking along, but during missions that depend upon nightfall at a certain time, you get free time to explore in case you want to forestall nightfall. There really isnt much to do at night so far other than run for you life and fail 50% of the time. The npc hunters are very efficient at surrounding your location even if you just sit still without making a peep. But I also haven't mastered all the night time techniques yet either, like setting off traps at the proper moments, using flares and the UV flashlight. Still, making a successful run to a safe zone with hunters at your back is incredibly exhilarating and gratifying, but only if you succeed

Dying Light is a vast open-world post-apocalyptic survival horror game combining the best features of various genres-   1) An RPG system that progressively allows you to become stronger, so that every time you level up you are better equipped with a variety of new skills to fight and survive- from martial arts to acrobatic moves that let you grapple, slide, stun, hook and perform incredible combinations of moves with stunning visual effect  2) Free-Running is one of the best aspects of the game. As you start out, you are weak and slow, but once you rank up and improve your skills you move significantly faster and are able to traverse the urban landscapes much better. Your feet rarely have to touch the ground as you jump and grapple-hook and climb your way across rooftops, scale buildings, slide along railings and swing from structure to structure at amazing heights  3) Crafting- in a world where you must scavenge to survive, you will spend alot of time exploring to find the best materials to improve the weak weapons you pick up, transforming them into slaughtering tools with a combination of elemental effects that shock, poison, burn, freeze, bleed and much more! You also are able to add upgrades to improve the damage, handling and durability of each weapon. However, to prevent players from using only one weapon indefinitely, there is a maximum number of repairs available  4) Survival Horror- Dying Light is a true survival horror game, and you never feel at ease, especially at night when you can barely see even with flares and flashlights. Hunting you are creatures of the night that can parkour as well. You must utilise your skills of stealth and/or parkour to effectively evade these creatures, or spend much of your ammunition and health trying to confront and hopefully, defeat them  This is, in my opinion, the best survival horror game ever made and it is a must-buy and must-play for all fans of the genre. There are many side quests, challenges, quarantine zones to do beside the main story, and you will also spend alot of time scavenging and looking for air drops. This game should take an average of 50-80 hours to fully complete.

I'm sprinting through an alley as I make my way to my objective, when I hear the sound of a plane flying overhead. I climb up to the nearest rooftop and wait for the flair indicating the location of the next supply drop to go off. It's quite a ways east of my location, but I don't mind the exercise. As I make my way across the rooftops, a message warning me that I should make my way indoors plays over my walkie talkie. The sun is setting, and that's when the Volatiles come out to play.  I don't have time for sleep though. By the time the sun comes back up, the supply drop will have already been taken by Rais' men, and we will lose more of our people if we don't get our hands on some more Antizin.  Suddenly the trail of rooftops I was following ends, and between me and the supply drop is a horde of Biters. I don't have time to think. I leap off the top of the building I'm on, and immediately toss my grappling hook at a nearby lamppost, pulling myself back up after just being inches from the ground. I spare no time scouting out a safe path to the supply drop, and leap from lappost to lamppost as the Biters below mindlessly follow.  I hear a familiar scream from the horde though. A Viral is among them, and easily matches my pace. I begin using my grappling hook more often now. That's the only advantage I have over this recently infected runner. If only he had known that his attempt at being a hero would end up making the lives of the uninfected all the more difficult.  I leap off the final lamppost in the row, and land just feet away from the supply drop. The Viral is right behind me though, and executing him with a gun wouldn't be a wise decision. He's wielding a crowbar, and matches me blow for blow. Dispatching of him is time consuming, and several Volatiles are making their way through the horde of Biters.   I begin my task of picking the lock on the supply drop crate as I hear the growling of the Volatiles get closer and closer.  The crate's open, and I grab the Antizen inside.  I don't waste time turning around to find out how close a call it was, and sprint away from the scene toward the nearest safe house.  ___________________________________________________   Dying Light is basically what Dead Island should have been. It's nothing like you've ever played before, but easily a hybrid of Mirror's Edge, and maybe Far Cry and Dead Island. Never mind the story, you're a survivor living in the city of the undead, and the playground is massive. There's two large sized maps, one of which you start out in, and another you unlock about halfway through the story. There's dozens of side missions for you to complete and unlock unique weapons and blueprints through. There's three skill trees related to Survivability, Parkour, and Weapons for you to level up individually and earn game changing abilities from.  By the time you near the end of the game, you're no longer the same survivor you were originally playing as. You unlock so many abilities that while navigating the city becomes easier, dispatching of enemies becomes more difficult as they gain strength alongside you.  And while there are no difficulty settings, the player can stick to doing missions during the nighttime while the Volatiles are out, making the game a lot more difficult, and rewarding them with twice the amount of experience they would have earned during the daytime.  There's also seamless, drop-in, drop-out, 4-player co-op that doesn't put any limitations on what you can do versus what you can do by yourself.  Did I mention that the PvP mode in this game is essentially a better version of the unreleased 'Evolve' game? The game pits 1-4 humans against a single player-controlled zombie, as they try and navigate the city at night, destroying nests.  Dying Light is well worth the purchase, and it won't surprise me if it makes it into some of the lists for 2015's Top 10 games, despite releasing so early on in the year.

Equipment is bound to the left trigger, equipment can be thrown objects or ya know equipment. Dying Light is a zombie survival game with a great story and totally awesome combat system, and a day/cycle that drastically changes how you play.  The game doesn't run optimally on my computer as of yet, but there is a post by the devs saying a fix is coming.  Even with these issues, this is still easily the best game I've ever played.  These are the reasons why sorted by what is most important to me.  Co-op Gameplay: It's the little things that make this game special, and the unique way you can kill zombies with your friends is awesome. My buddy was holding a propane tank and told me to hit it, so i did... He threw the tank into a horde of zombies blowing up at least five. It was amazing. While both you and your friend are in a menu the game will pause as it would in single player. Loot is personal so if you find something tell your friends to come too, no need to feel greedy.. TAKE EVERYTHING. Parkour running and literally jumping off zombies heads is also more fun with friends.  Day/Night Cycle: During the day we were badasses running around killing zombies, we took out a beast of a zombie with a huge weapon and even managed to beat up some of the thugs you find in the world. We ran the city... Then is was dark out, and suddenly we were hunted by the terrifying Virals. These zombies are loud and hunt in packs. When one finds you, they all find you. We spent whole first night running for our lives, evading pursuits and then sneaking around to objectives. Eventually day came and we were rewarded with Survivor Points, one of the game's forms of experience. Once again we were the badasses. We decided we're going to play the whole game through without skipping to day time (as this is an option). We'll see how it goes.  Loot Management/Weapon Repairs: Some people call this a negative but this is an element of the game that puts so many questions into my head. What might be useful? What do I have a lot of? What should I sell? What can I craft? What do I need to go find? You can upgrade your weapon and modify it, but eventually its going to break and be useless. Which means you need to lockpick police vans or hunt down some thugs to find new weapons or currency to buy new weapons. You will always need items to craft upgrades. Weapons are everywhere so don't worry about not having them. It's just more fun to kill for a while with a super badass upgraded weapon you crafted.  Combat System/Skill Trees: When you first begin your adventure you have low stamina, which means few hits and lots of falling back away from zombies, but as you level your Power skill tree you gain unique abilities like throwing stars and powerful strikes as well as the stamina upgrade.  In the Agility skill tree you can you learn how to vault off of zombies up to roofs, dropkick them into spikes, on to burning cars, into electrified water.. the possibilities seem endless and I'm excited to see how far I can progess my character. These skills mesh nicely with the combat system and eventually give you the feeling that you can climb and run anywhere and kick and smash anyone.  Open World Gameplay: There are a ton of side objectives that will pop up on your map at any given time, you don't have to participate, but the reawrds can often be very nice. Loot respawns so you can visit an area you found some good stuff at, zombies respawn so you can keep on chillin and killin... Need I say more. I love open world games.  The Story: Crane...rhymes with brain and train and plain and the other kind of plane. This guy is thrown into the apocalypse as some sort of undercover agent. I don't want to give too much away, but he has to deal with some conflict between his orders and his morals. I enjoyed the seriousness of the story as well as the funny little dialouges, and the insight you get from loading screens listening to your character's journal logs.   *The Cons: Like I said at the start, the game isn't running at 100% optimization on my machine yet. So I can't comment on graphics at this point. I will say the motion blur seems a little over the top. You want those types of things to barely visible, but when my buddy dropkicks a zombie he turns into the flash. Not a gamebreaker but kind of annoying.   OVERALL - A great game when enjoyed with at least one friend, four player co-op is probably amazing.  9/10 - Would dropkick 10,000 more zombies 10,000 more times.

I wanted a game in which 'running away' was the most legit method of dealing with a shambling hoard of flesh eating monsters. I wanted a game where 'but I can REACH that roof' was a fine method of escape. I wanted a game where I was rewarded for intelligent behavior in a crisis, not reckless.  Behold: Dying Light - a game that in less that 30 minutes did what my parents were unable to do for years (when I was younger and stupider): enforce a GOD DAMNED CURFEW.  'XP is doubled at night!' Yeah, I'll bet it is. The game could seriously offer to rain down free AK-47s at night and I would still hoof my way back to a safehouse, crawl to my little soiled mattress, and hit the 'F' key to skip ahead to the morning every time.  This game is fun. It has the right combination of survivalishness, FPSness, and Mirror's Edge. You can fight the zombies - and are given tons of tools for doing so. However, fighting the zombies is not your job. Your job is to find crap, fix crap, and live to tell about it. You'll have to skull thump a zombie here and there. And there. And again. And AGAIN- STAY DOWN YOU CR- sorry, distracted. But the real meat of the game is avoiding them. The game is also not too cruel in your failing - if you do find yourself around a bunch of zombies, getting away isn't a trial.  ... unless it is night. At night, the SCARY zombies come out. They're faster than you. They leap higher than you. I think some of them shoot lasers. I'm not sure. I think you can fight them too - again, I'm not sure. I tried and one of them ate my face. Then I tried running and another one ate my face. Lots of face-eating. You have to learn to distract, use your tools wisely, activate traps, and run your ♥♥♥ over to a safezone ASAP. You're both forced to learn an area and think quickly.  Overall, it is pretty fun. And pretty. I haven't played for more than a few hours, but I still enjoy it. So far I'm only venturing into single player - and let me tell you now, the story mode is... interesting. Give it time. Let it stupidly handicap you for an hour or so until you get your freedom. Then? Run. Frolic. LIVE!  Just be back before dark.

An absolutely fantastic game.  [GAMEPLAY] Looking back on Dead Island & Riptide, after playing this game, it seems like the developers really have learned from their experiences. Instead of picking a character already focused on one type of combat & upgrading from there, you are free to customise your character as you see fit, which can lead to creating a character that not only fits your play style, but will influence your strategy in surviving in the game world. The game rewards strategic thinking.  It also rewards skill. The lockpicking from Skyrim is here, but without the unlockable character upgrades that can make it easier to open harder chests. It is simply down to your skill. Similiarly, gun-use does not require an unlockable upgrade, which if you play FPSs is hartily appreciated, as you don’t suck at guns for the first half of the game. What does upgrade is your bag, your free-running, your capability with hand-to-hand weapons - their use & their mantainance, your crafting & your health. You gain upgrade points by completing missions or helping random strangers you come across for SURVIVOR uprades, fighting for POWER upgrades & free-running for Agility upgrades, which can lead to you one-hitting zombies or sprinting along walls Prince of Persia style. And you are rewarded for combinations of jumps, landings, attacks & timing, which creates a REAL feeling of progression, as you see what is benefiting you.   Every time you run into something that might get stale, you find the developers have dropped in new elements to keep things fresh. Every now & again you will run into a new type of zombie as the story progresses, which will force you to find new ways to fight them, or to focus on different upgrades or weapons to even the odds. Also, halfway through the game you gain access to a new district, akin to Shadow of Mordor but, unlike SoM, the area has changed so much that your approach to playing changes as well, requiring a slightly altered style of play; a fresh challange against which to pit the skills you honed in the last area.  There is also the day/night cycle. You are rewarded a boost to XP for Agility & Power at night &, not only are certain enemies more powerful, but new faster, stronger & more durable enemies appear. Meaning you can sleep through the night OR you can choose to go and about trusting your agility to guide you through, or just wade in when your feel yourself strong enough. And crafted gadgets like firecrackers & flares (which ward off the big bads) make this actually do-able, when at first it seems like a mad prospect!  The game is very well put together, providing well-balanced & varied enemies so that you cannot just climb up high or run really fast & expect to breeze through & avoid danger, you have to engage with it & REALLY play the game. Similiarly, if you don't want to play at night, you don't have to. But there are parts of the story where you are forced to act against your inclinations & embrace night running, presenting you with the hard opportunity to either just run, praying, or think about it strategically, should you ever be caught out again. (The camouflage ability came in really handy for me in those situations, which was a strategic choice I didn't have to make and, without it, I would have needed to play very differently to survive.)  The free running mechanic is also extremely well-polished &, after a little while, you get a sense for what distances you can cross, what ledges you can make it to, & this also presents an interesting way to approach quests, since you can approach enemy camps from above as well as below. Finding your own way, via your own ingenuity is extremely satisfying.   [GRAPHICS] The graphics for the game look brilliant. The faces for some characters could be better done & there is the occasional cloning of very minor npcs, but the regular, major & critical NPCs look well, individual & everything from weapons, to gore, to the city itself looks great. The atomsphere is very well done indeed: rain is wet, the world & you will be soaked. Get soaked at your vision will be compromised. It looks & feels exactly like it should. Also, the night is daaaaark, like it should be.   (I ended up in a really nerve-wracking area & found myself telling the character to wipe his bleeping eyes already so I could see! All of it works to heighten the tension. Similarly, at one point he was exhausted and his breathing was loud & heavy, & I found myself worrying that the undead might actually hear it, since they react to all kinds of sounds in the world, which leads us to...)   [SOUND] Thunder, water, rain, impact sounds, sloughing guts - it all sounds like it should, pulling you in. The undead also make different sounds, which will have you turning about looking for the extra dangerous one you just heard shriek as it spotted you. There are ambient sounds of distant fires, fighting, monster & human screams - when you are moving about through a dangerous area & someone (there are a number of different types) screams distantly 'HELP ME!', or just cries out in terror, you hear it but the way it is generated leaves you wondering what direction it came from, giving the city a feeling of living terror that is constantly shifting and moving, and it fits superbly.  The music too is fitting & some tracks are great to listen to. The menu music alone had me sitting listening for a few moments every time I loaded up the game to get me into the feel of it. I still listen to it after having completed the game.  [STORY & CHARACTERS] The main characters, from the kid who you worry isn't old enough to take charge, to the guy who rallied the first survivors you meet, to the woman you run with (trying to avoid spoilers), and practically across the board, all have their own back stories & many have stories that have influenced the city in some way, you cross posters for some, & meet random survivors who have met or know of others. The stories are nuanced as well, & aren’t rammed down your throat, you get a sense of the person from your time with them & from what others say, which allows you to not only bond with the characters you like but also to fill in the pieces of their back story specifically left out because it isn't pertinent to what they are saying at the time, which feels more realistic.  While there has been the occasional complaint about the main bad guy being something of a stereotype, his backstory (discovered in-game) reveals that he was a very different man up until a short while ago, and even when first the quarantine first arrived. But, now, he is exactly the type of person this crisis would create. Someone who's mind has shifted to see things differently, aiding his survival.  And the story is strong enough, with both your own mission and the added element of the people you get to know and need to protect, that it keeps the momentum up. Regular breaks with new orders from your bosses outside the quarantine give you an actual moral tie to the game and the people you are either helping or putting in danger with your actions. And the fact that side missions tend to build on themselves, creating new issues that arise from other missions make it feel like a more vibrant and alive experience.   [OVERALL] This is solid game that anticipates the lulls that exist in open world gameplay & actually addresses them to keep things fresh. It is fast, and rewarding and has just the right amount of everything to keep you playing. The peaks and troughs that exist in open world games are a shadow of what they were. The peaks are still there, but you don't feel like your are are wasting time with busy work until your next story mission. It is definitely one I would recommend. I'm already feeling its absence now that I've finished it.
