This is the ZOMBIE GAME that delievers. Incredible graphics throbbing with excellent optimization. I had my LOD set to 0 yet i was still getting mind blowing far off views. I can only imagine what its like set to full. Npcs are lifelike in appearance and the world is so fully realised in its detailed environments i feel like am actually there. The only way it could get any more real is with one of those up and coming virtual reality headsets.   Audio and music brings home the classic eerie nightmare feel of a George Romero, Lucio Fulci, Ford Brothers zombie movie with just the right balance of real life ambience and theatrical stimuli. Voice acting is marvelous giving life to npcs and your character while enhancing further the believabilty of the amazing highly fleshed out world.  As you play through the game your character will level up getting skill points depending on what he does most in the game. If they are a runner type their agility tree will get skill points to use on different strengths. If they are a smash and kill every undead in sight type they will get skill points in their power tree etc.  The environment is very tactile with tons of things you can interact with. From turning on radios to collecting common day items you can then use to craft new things with like weapons and home made health kits. You can pick locks of different levels of difficulty but be weary time will not stop and a zombie may chomp into your skull because you didnt pay mind to its shuffling feet as you greedily picked a locked chest. You can rummage through buildings for food and money while coming across people in need of help. If you decide to help them it will effect how they view you. If not oh well you scoundrel you! Movement is also another spectacular very natural feeling action executed in spectaculer fashion by DYING LIGHT finding myself climbing and jumping onto and off buildings, diving under things etc etc. Usually i suck at games that have acrobatics but in DYING LIGHT it all felt so right with the parkour system.  You will see npcs going about their daily lives while having to deal with the horrors of the zombie plague. One time i came across a bunch of children in a day care school setting in a apartment building as a female teacher read them children stories. Another time i listened to one of the many varied accounts of those fighting zombies as i explored a building.  Combat is alot of fun as well as quite scary. While you engage zombies your stamina will go down making your attacks less effective and you more vulnerable to a zombie(s) assault. Zombies may be slow moving but they will tear you apart as you scream in horror when you suddenly find yourself surrounded by a slow moving horde of rotting corpses.   Your weapons have wear and tear which means that metal pipe will be useless after one too many door smashed open by it or zombie skull caved in. Fear not though for you can repair your items back to working shape with items you salvage in the world.  DYING LIGHT its the ELDER SCROLLS and METRO 2033/METRO LAST LIGHT of zombie games. Truly a mind blowing masterpiece that will give you hours upon hours of endless gameplay with a awesome campaign and plenty of side quests.  To have this much enjoyment from my i5-3570k 3.40ghz with 8.0gb ram, Radeon HD 7770 card at a resolution of 1366x768 is miraculous. All i can say is thanks and DYING LIGHT is definitely a title worth playing and paying full price for.  DYING LIGHT a magnificent and rare treasure of a game.

First off, the short version is yes, this game is worth the money and isn't a buggy, unplayable, DLC ridden mess from the get go. The combat is fun and visceral, and the parkour elements are fun once you get used to them. The keyboard controls are actually well done (This seems to be uncommon now for multiple platform games).   A quick breakdown of pros and cons I've seen so far:  Pros:  You feel like you're buying two games at once. The nighttime mechanics change the game and how you play a TON. While you can mow through zombies during the day once you find your first decent weapon, once the sun sets, you'll be dodging for safe houses QUICK. While nighttime becomes far less deadly once you begin modding premium katanas and such, for a good portion of the game it will be dangerous, and truly makes you play like a survivor in a post-apocalyptic world.  The background music and ambient sounds are amazing. You'll be able to discern where and how close mobs are to you, and the chanting/moaning music really makes the gameplay more suspenseful, especially at night. The first time a screamer got behind me at night I almost ♥♥♥♥♥♥ myself.  The graphics are stunning, although some builds may need to turn them down until another optimization patch hits. For what it's worth, I'm running a Nvidia GTX770 with an I7 CPU and it runs on max perfectly. Your mileage may vary.  The game supports multiple playstyles, you can either be a true runner, springing from rooftop to rooftop to avoid the infectious horde, or go to town on their heads with a baseball bat.  The co-op in this game is a true co op experience, where you can run through the campaign together and you both get progress, or you can invade a friend as a super-zombie and try to eat him alive!  There is a massive amount of content with sidequests and story. After playing for 30 hours, I believe I've just hit the 25% progress mark.  Cons:  I'm suspect of the replay value once you complete all the quests. The game does have a NG+ mode, but the weapon customization is not in depth enough to keep you grinding for a true super weapon, so it'll essentially be more of the same.  Some PC builds have problems running the game due to bottlenecked CPU requirements. For now, the game seems to utilize one core, regardless of how many cores are in your CPU.  And I can't believe I'm saying this, but torwards the end of the game, you are much too strong at night. Once you mod an orange katana, you'll one hit everything except the beefiest night-only mobs, and even then they only take 2-3 shots to kill.    Overall, it's a very good game worth the pricetag, and is a must have if you have a spouse or friend you enjoy playing zombie games with.  9/10, would dropkick zombies off a bridge again.

I wanted a game in which 'running away' was the most legit method of dealing with a shambling hoard of flesh eating monsters. I wanted a game where 'but I can REACH that roof' was a fine method of escape. I wanted a game where I was rewarded for intelligent behavior in a crisis, not reckless.  Behold: Dying Light - a game that in less that 30 minutes did what my parents were unable to do for years (when I was younger and stupider): enforce a GOD DAMNED CURFEW.  'XP is doubled at night!' Yeah, I'll bet it is. The game could seriously offer to rain down free AK-47s at night and I would still hoof my way back to a safehouse, crawl to my little soiled mattress, and hit the 'F' key to skip ahead to the morning every time.  This game is fun. It has the right combination of survivalishness, FPSness, and Mirror's Edge. You can fight the zombies - and are given tons of tools for doing so. However, fighting the zombies is not your job. Your job is to find crap, fix crap, and live to tell about it. You'll have to skull thump a zombie here and there. And there. And again. And AGAIN- STAY DOWN YOU CR- sorry, distracted. But the real meat of the game is avoiding them. The game is also not too cruel in your failing - if you do find yourself around a bunch of zombies, getting away isn't a trial.  ... unless it is night. At night, the SCARY zombies come out. They're faster than you. They leap higher than you. I think some of them shoot lasers. I'm not sure. I think you can fight them too - again, I'm not sure. I tried and one of them ate my face. Then I tried running and another one ate my face. Lots of face-eating. You have to learn to distract, use your tools wisely, activate traps, and run your ♥♥♥ over to a safezone ASAP. You're both forced to learn an area and think quickly.  Overall, it is pretty fun. And pretty. I haven't played for more than a few hours, but I still enjoy it. So far I'm only venturing into single player - and let me tell you now, the story mode is... interesting. Give it time. Let it stupidly handicap you for an hour or so until you get your freedom. Then? Run. Frolic. LIVE!  Just be back before dark.

Had fun playing it, was long but didn't drag out, story missions were a little weak, but everything else makes up for it.  Game play is good, parkour can be alittle hard to get used to at first, but once you do, you'll notice it missing in other games. Melee combat is good, doesn't get out of hand like in Dead Rising, and even when your at full power(max levels) you can still be overwhelmed by the zombies if not careful.  Had a nice variety of melee weapons, but didn't like escalation of melee weapon damage, making some of your favorite weapons obsolete, and alot of the weapon craft recipes obsolete also. Probably could of done it another way, but it's not a deal breaker. The variety of grenades would of been nice if at least half of them were effective, but the ones that work, really work, while the others were just wasted resources. Another thing about melee combat: why can't you parry like the human NPC's can?  Gun combat was probably the weakest part of the game, variety of firearms sucks, and the ones you do get generally don't get used much because of the noise they generate. No Suppressors for firearms. Minor spoiler, later in the game you run into someone who should be able to make them, but nope. You can craft all kinds of weird stuff, but no suppressors. There were a few times your pretty much forced to use firearms, and when you do, they just don't 'feel' right. They do work though, you just won't be using them much.  Day/night cycle was great. During the day, you scavenge, get stuff done. There is danger, but for the most part you can get into and out of trouble without dying(going to want to concentrate on building up agility at first, mobility is the key to survival). Night, well, it's been awhile since a game has made me nervous. Nighttime in this game is deadly. Other types of zombies come out to play, and even at the later levels its pretty easy to get killed. Unless you play with the gamma up, it's DARK. You eventually do get some night vision, but when you do venture out at night, you need a plan. It helps greatly to get familiar with your surroundings, the closest safe house, and the path there.  Variety of enemies is mixed. Human enemies come in the have guns and don't have guns variety. They can be a pain to fight, though you will figure out a few tactics that make them easy to kill. Nice variety of zombies, most are the slow kind, but even that can be deceptive because some of them are as quiet as the grave and can sneak up on you if your not paying attention. There are some fast ones, some tough ones, and then there are the ones at night who are fast, tough, and generally unkillable until later in the game. Even then, they like to call for help, so again, night combat is hit and run.  There are a small variety of activities that can give you something to do, and alot of them will at least help you level up, if not give you weapon upgrades and recipes. Don't let the story rush you, far as I can tell there is no time limit. The story missions...meh. Some were good, but I really hated how they forced you into situations. They will take control of the clock, so even if you started in the morning, you could wind up out at night. Or gear is taken away from you(they at least give you the option of getting it back, but it only made sense once). And the end fight is anticlimatic at best. Still, not deal breaker,  The game world itself is nice. Graphics look good, and the world itself shows that they put effort into this. Nice variety of locations, and even traveling from one end of the map to the other didn't feel like a chore most times. Exploring would yield rewards much of the time, and there are all kinds of out of the way or almost hidden places. You can jump or climb to almost any place, though some places did take alittle thinking to get to. Another thing, heights. I hate heights. I actually got a bit of vertigo climbing some of the towers.  All in all, I loved playing this game. Room for improvement, sure. But this is one of the best games I've played in a long while.

This is one of my all time favorite games. Like many people say, the storyline may not be that great, as it is very predictable and 'cliche', however the gameplay is simply incredible. From the bery beginning, you are able to parkour and free-run wherever you want, whenever you want. Also, as you progress in the game, you unlock even more abilities, such as being able to use zombies as footstools, dropkicking zombies in the face, and running straight through hordes of enemies by tackling them all to the ground. All of the abilities you unlock allow your movement throught the map to become so fluid that you can get to anywhere you want without stopping. The fighting mechanics and abilities are also outstanding. Just like the parkour aspect, you unlock more abilities as you grow stronger, allowing you to grapple enemies to the ground, drop on their heads from rooftops assassin's creed style, and throw your weapon straight into a zombie's brain. The third primary aspect of the game, 'survival', is just as well polished as the others. The longer you survive, the more proficient you become at doing. You can learn how to pick locks, create powerful elixirs to boost your abilities, and even use a grappling hook to get to hard to reach areas.  The weapon system is also very well done. As you level up, you can obtain stronger weapons, and you can also modify them and upgrade them using blueprints and materials you find throughout the map. In conclusion, this game is awesome. The gameplay makes you feel like Chuck Norris, and if you play it too much, you might actually start to think you are. The only bad part about it is that you have to have a beefy computer to run it, which might crush alot of dreams for some people (I had to buy a new graphics card just to run it). Anyway, other than needing amazing computer specs (and the horrible DLC's), I give this game 5 stars.

While most people may look over this as being 'Yet another zombie game', let it be said that it isn't. While some may skip over it, thinking back to how unpolished Dead Island was, one would be pleased to know that they have not made the same mistake.  This game sets an example that needs to be followed, the amount of bugs are fairly low, and yes, there may be performance issues, but no game shall ever be perfect. The polish in this game is unlike i've ever seen, to the way the particle effects react, such as smoke slowly spreading to a room in an abandoned apartment after opening a door, the way the lighting is done, where a flashlight isn't just shining light on the nearest wall, but actually providing a cone of light, even in the void of night. The way the enemy strength isn't shown to you with a number, but by changing their appearence subtly, to the point where i only noticed the pattern over halfway into the game.  Sure, some of the enemies might be a bit easy, and some may be annoying in a very unfair way, such as one enemy being able to fire upon you, yet being nowhere to be found, they have however kept the fear in the night, to the point where once you are at the highest power you can be, you think to yourself you can take everything on without trouble, but the Volatiles, they are always kept as terrifying as in the beginning, because while you may kill one or two, more will come, and you will not be able to stop them.  The movement system, being from someone who absolutely loved Mirror's Edge, was brilliant, and while one may want something such as horizontal wall running, it may have felt a bit too unrealistic if done wrong, and while you get a grappling hook, you cannot use it to completely bypass any obstacle, which i feel is fair, for why would you want to get away from such a massive part of the game?  The story manages to be original, considering the medium is very heavily used, you actually grow to like the characters, which many games fail to do. And finally, while Troy Baker might be becoming the new Nolan North, this might be one of his greatest performances, especially near the end, the emotion in his voice is something many voice actors cannot replicate.  As for the problems, there are performance issues, some of the challenges in the game can be anger inducing due to focusing on a specific mechanic, such as cutting zombies in half, and there are some inconsistancies in the story (one of which, is only due to keeping a gameplay mechanic in, for removing it for the second half of the game would have been a horrible idea), but overall, 45 hours, none of which was with repetitive gameplay such as grinding or multiplayer (be the zombie), which is much more than many games can provide in this age of gaming.  Let's just hope that this game sets a new bar, and that we get to see more games with this level of care put into it.

I'll start with this: Dying Light is worth every bit of the price of entry. I can't remember the last time I've enjoyed myself this much in a zombie game. Almost everything about the game kept bringing me back to one word: fun.   Bashing zombie's: fun. Running around large, mostly open world: fun. Upgrading your abilities based on how you played the game: fun. Jumping from building to building and juuuuust barely making it onto that terrace: fun. Finding parts and upgrading weapons to make some kind of toxic, flame sword: fun. Creating and using a grapling hook: super fun. Picking a lot and carefully listening for something to come up behind me and kill me: fun. Thinking I could probably take on that horde of zombies, finding out I can't and barely escaping with my life: fun. Clearing out new safe houses: fun. Running for my life every single time the sun went down: fun. This game just nailed combat, movement, and the rpg elements. Add all this to the fact that there is a distinctly '80s vibe to the whole thing and I was in love.  About 2/3 of the way through my play time, however; things started to break down about. There didn't seem to be any new enemies to fear or present any kind of real challenge. I'd realized pretty early that there really wasn't any reason or advantage to be out at night, but the lack of safe houses meant I would sometimes get stuck out there do to poor planning on my part. Once I'd cleared out all the safe houses I was never far enough away from one at night so that I couldn't just get to one and go to sleep until morning. The grapling hook that I loved, made the game a bit too easy at times, allowing for quick escapes from bad situations where my lack of forword thought should have gotten me killed. As great as melee combat was, the gun play is a bit boring. I found myself saying 'another gun fight?' way too often and wished that they would have just stuck with melee weapons or made amunition waaay harder to come by so that you really had to think about every bullet you fired. Finally, the last boss in the story missions was such a let down, and when I really thought about it, there was nothing else it could have been. In a world of crazy, blood thirsty, sometimes mutant zombies, just some bad dude with a machette really wasn't comparable.   Techland did so much right with Dying Light and I think that's made the mistakes stand out more. Still, I would recommend this it to anyone, even if only for the first 2/3s of the game.

What a pleasant surprise this turned out to be..  I hadn't heard anything about this game, even after it was released. I learned about it from the commercials after launch. I decided to purchase it after watching some streams online.   What a great game. I'm 32 and have been feeling a little bored with games lately. Dying Light came in, and I've started enjoying firing up the old PC and getting online for some multiplayer again.   Graphics: Outstanding. The first thing that caught my attention was the detail Techland paid to creating a believable world in Harran. From enormously long view distances, to the varying weather patterns, day and night cycle (more on nights later), blood splattering on you and NPC's after smashing a few zombies heads, to the effects of the wind on the palm trees and characters clothing, the graphics are a joy to take in with the settings turned up.   Gameplay: Who would have thought parkour and zombies would be such a great combo? I really enjoy playing this game. I can spend hours just free running the city, challenging myself to go farther and farther without stopping my sprint. The game is beautifully violent, with dismemberment, decapitations, and heads smashing GALORE. The game features a deep skill tree over three seperate categories, and I like how you are penalized for dying by losing your survivor points. The missions do not feel like chores, and I appreciate how Techland spent the extra time planning the side missions to add value to them. The side missions have some story to them, and do a great job of showing off the different elements to the gameplay. As much fun as the game is in single player, it really shines when you can get a group of three other players who enjoy cooperating and communication to join up with, and progress the story together. The feeling of dread on my first playthrough during the first night was amazing. Techland really nailed the atmosphere, and the fear factor when you start dealing with the pursuits. The multiplayer component also includes a competitive aspect with the ability to play as a hunter and invade other players games. The resulting chess match of the humans weapons and items vs. the overpowered abilities of the hunter is damn fun, and didn't feel unfair at all, especially when you have a couple of people helping watch your back during an invasion. I enjoyed Dead Island's multi, but the game was so sloppy and unpolished that it broke the immersion for me and just couldn't save it in my opinion. This is what Dead Island should have been.   Sound: The voice acting is above average, and did not get on my nerves as most games scripting and voice acting will. All of the sounds of sledgehammers crushing skulls, military rifles unloading on a group of zombies, and the resulting screams of virals in the distance who are now alerted to your presence are presented wonderfully over my speakers, and even better over my surround headset. The positional audio is spot on.   Overall: One of the best games I've ever played to be honest. I love me a good, violent video game, and this one delivers. I love the carnage, and the visceral imagery on display in Dying Light. It's fun to screw around in, and has a solid story line to be played when you get bored of screwing around. The physics system is great, so many lol worthy moments to be had once you you get the grasp of the controls and skills. Cheers to Techland for doing such a good job with Dying Light, and proving that I'm not getting too old to enjoy a video game afterall. I highly recommend buying this game.   10/10

At the time of writing this review, I just made it to the second city.  The Story: Decent. Not bad, but not good. It can keep you intrigued for a while.  Parkour: Near Flawless. Taking inspiration from Mirror's Edge, this is my favorite part. Sometimes my hand gets stuck in the model I'm climbing on to, but that is only a minor detail. You'll be using this alot, as it easily surpasses murdering every zombie on the street. You'll be using this alot during Night time.  Combat: For the first 4-6 hours you'll mainly be using melee weapons. The comabt is similar to Dead Island's (because it's by the same developer, Techland), which is a good thing. But this time around, you don't have a health bar for your enemies. Aim for the head. Sometimes, you might have to run away to heal or repair your weapons, adding to the realism. About the time you get to the second city, it'll be the following guns: Military Rifle, Police Rifle, German 9mm Pistol, and the Double-Barrelled Shotgun. They're a little overpowered. Thankfully they don't give as much exp.  The Lag: If you have a decent modern gaming rig, you might be able to run it. I'd stay away if your graphics card is not in the Minimum/Recommended specs. Hopefully they patch most of it. I have to stay at about the lowest settings to get an average of 40 fps. Easily better for consoles.  Graphics: With the lag comes the pay off. Graphics. They are excellent. (Not the all-time best I've seen) In my opinion though, it's gameplay over graphics.  Extra Content: This game has a long campaign. But what if you wanted to do more? Side quests are everywhere and are plentiful. The Season Pass might be worth $20.00 if you like the game (I bought it with the Ultimate Edition). Some of the side quests characters can be weird though...  Rating: 8.5/10 If you have a great gaming rig. 7/10  If you have a decent gaming rig. 9.9/10 For parkour fans. 8.5/10 For combat fans. 9/10 For Linux support (why not Mac then too?)  Overall Rating: 8.2/10 Past it's lag and overpowered weapons late-game, it teaches you how to survive by avoiding zombies instead of straight up murdering them. Enemies take a lot to take down (besides with the insta-kill headshot guns, which is logical) so you might have to run away and repair your weapons or heal. The Side Quests and Season Pass will keep you entertained with extra content once you beat the Campaign. Co-op with your friends (which I haven't played) is cool. It's worth $60.00 if you have a great gaming rig.

At first you can only swing a melee weapon 3 or 4 times before your character becomes winded and out of breath. Even a group of three slow zombies can be a serious threat in the right situation. And that's really fun. One of my critiques is that I think you can level up your character too much. Fighting during the day becomes less challenging and more boring. Fighting at night and against the stronger specials gets to the point where it is about just right, but I would rather the two levels of difficulty meet a little more in the middle and have the character gain less power overall.  Weapons are pretty good too: using melee weapons is fun as hell and i think i played about 10 hours before I even found a gun. I used it in a panick to kill three thugs who cornered me later on and i used up the whole mag, rendering the gun useless. Firing a gun is one of the worst decisions you can make in the game, as it draws hordes of the undead. It's definitely a last resort, which I like. Unfortunately, the game is absolutely littered with weapons to find and you will be constantly be deciding which items to dump from your inventory to make room for the shiny new scimitar you found. Weapons also suffer from becoming too powerful and thus, boring.   This is probably the only zombie game I've played that truly fits the fiction of a zombie apocalypse and caters to the rules of surviving in such a scenario.  The story is pretty much straight trash. The villain is uninspired, the ending is anticlimactic and frustrating, and theres a pretty sexist damsel in distress sequence. Much like far cry, the game excels when it hands freedom to you rather than story missions or QTE's.   The root of the gameplay is crazy fun and takes a long time to get old. It took me 40 hours just to complete the base story, so its a good time/money investment. The open world is great as well, but there is no fast traveling. Usually this isnt a problem because the running is so fun. But towards the end of the game when you are running the sewer gauntlet between halves of the map again and again it gets pretty annoying.   Overall, solid game.

Note: I have played about 14 hours in total (about 64% through the game on my playthrough) however I played it mostly in Offline mode due to internet connection problems.  First of all: This game is remarkable; the graphics look stunning and the gameplay feels fluid and most of the times not staggered. The Parkour is alright to say the least, it isn't Mirror's Edge but it is tied in well enough to be fun most of the time - I have seen many people have problems with the port but I have to say that I have found no problems with any lag (Running on a GTX 760 4gb) and because I do not have an AMD card or any GTX 900 series cards - the main cause for concern with this title, I can only state that it should work fine with the 700 series.  The story is lackluster at best and leaves alot to be desired; it starts to pick up pace from about half way onwards but it still is nothing to write home about. The voice acting of Crane is monotone and at times obnoxious and later on he begins to put in more emphasis when more dramatic plot points come up but equally can't save it.  The combat is basically a more refined version of Dead Island's with more fluid animations and better feeling weapons that actually have a sort of weight behind them, when you decapitate a zombie with a knife or bash its head in with a pipe the Sound, Slow-Mo and X-Ray compliment it without it being in the way of actual combat.  Atmospherically this game has nailed it - being out at night is tense, especially at the start of the game when you have barely any decent weapons, and at day when you can see everything the city is eerie yet beautiful, nothing really seems out of place. I get a sort of Resident Evil 1 vibe from it at some points where I know something will happen, but I don't know when. The horror in the game is purely atmospheric, nothing will jump out at you and scream but the enviroments and lighting (or lack there-of) can be intimidating at times.  Finally, the tone is a massive contrast to Dead Island. Where Dead Island was colourful and vibrant, this game was dark and gritty; we talk about the infamous Dead Island trailer but at times I think that the trailer for that would fit this game better - still not perfect but much better because of the tone of the game.  In Conclusion; this game is incredible - it has it's flaws, as does everything, but it is already one of the best modern games that I have played and it will take alot to top it.

Review featured on  Virtualcrunch.com :  I’d like to start this review by pointing out that the studio who developed this title originally made Dead Island with the Publisher Deep Silver, who apparently made a lot of choices in Dead Islands’ development that Techland disagreed with. Because of this, I feel that Dying Light might just be the game Techland wanted to make from the beginning, and they are rightly proud of it. These guys deserve some recognition for setting out to perfect the creative vision they had for their game, and I can’t help but be glad they did.   Right out of the gate the first thing you’ll notice is how gorgeous this game is, and two, it feels like a typical military first person shooter, but it’s lying. After a quick briefing from the GRE over a radio, you are then thrown into the quarantined city of Haran, Turkey. Playing as the hired agent of the GRE, Kyle Crane, your mission is to infiltrate the factions that have surfaced within the ruined city and recover stolen documents before they are published to the world, subsequently jeopardizing the research on the virus conducted by your employers.  Near the beginning of the game you get a very empty impression of how much Crane really cares about the mission, the people, or the other survivors he meets throughout the city, and this feeling never really left me until near the end. Among the survivors you meet there is a kickboxing legend named Jade, her younger reckless brother Rahim and the leader of the Tower, Brecken. As a parkour instructor, Brecken seems to have gotten stuck as the leading survivalist in this urban landscape because of his undeniable skill at movement against the mostly sluggish and hungry hordes. Crane himself is portrayed as a simple man struggling with choices between his mission and doing the right thing. This is laid on so heavily so early it was hard to even gauge him on a personal level, especially since I found a lot of his choices very contradicting and confusing at times.  The story is one of the few major things that shy away from what you can’t ignore; This game has glaring similarities to Dead Island. From the melee weapon modifications to the “safe area filled with quests”, this game beckons to it’s older brother constantly. Keeping this in mind, every similarity is improved significantly. The combat is smoother and more effective, the quests have more story, purpose, and direction, giving you more information about what has really happened to the city of Harran. There is still the occasional “Go collect this random thing” side quests, but the quest giver is appropriately amazed that you would spend your time doing something so mundane. As a stranger to the Tower, Crane feels obligated to prove himself and gain peoples trust, so these kinds of quests are justified to me.  A lot of these quests offer up blueprints for new weapon modifications that are all too valuable to you in your mission to improve the effectiveness of your tools of zombie slaughter. These mods are varied quite well, with everything from adding extra blades for bleeding effects, blow torches to the edge of your axes, and even elemental additions to throwing weapons to freeze or engulf an enemy in flames. Craft Molotov’s, throwing stars out of metal and saw blades, and special UV flares that are effective against the strongest of the infected during the night. There are tools for every circumstance available.  With all of these weapons and tools to create and choose from, I still found myself gravitating towards the same tactics I used in Dead Island; Find the sharpest thing, make it sharper, swing for the neck and head only, and stomp on stuff a lot to save it’s durability points. Even with knowing this, cutting zombies in half (vertical and horizontal) and lobbing off several heads with a single swing is even more satisfying with the critical hit slow motion and X-ray effect the game features when landing a critical hit on a body part.  The game focuses its energy almost solely on melee combat, with gunplay coming in feeling like something extra. Shooting a gun feels a bit sluggish when aiming down the sight, and at some point ammo is plentiful as you fight through waves of human bandits armed to the teeth. Even so, the game promotes the instincts to reserve firing off your guns, as it makes noise and attracts runners to your area.  I was content saving my rifle ammo for dealing with human enemies from a distance, especially towards the beginning of the game when all you had was table legs and gas pipes to fight with against the formidable human melee fighters. It reminded me of fighting in Criminal Origins, dodging left and right, avoiding kicks and swings trying to find an opening in your opponent. Once you got your Power Skill tree high enough though, it only takes a few good swings to dispatch them and you barely even notice a struggle.  In fact this game’s progression felt very smooth and rewarding, only hindered by a frustrating and unnecessary experience point loss if you die. There is a tree for your overall Survivor rank, which includes abilities like a bigger backpack, creating drugs from the local herbs and improving your bartering skills for better prices. The Agility Tree focuses on ease of movement and evasion, dodging, sliding, vaulting off and over zombies are a few of the most useful examples. Movement is important for survival, to avoid zombies of course, but also to maneuver through the intricate and hazardous landscape. This game loves to place destructive zombies near explosives, or have water near an electrical source, turning one zombies simple movement into a possible deadly mess.  The third is the Power tree, which involves your combat abilities. Stealthy executions, kicks that stun your opponent, and more powerful slams and swings with your weapons make up the majority of this tree. Both your Power and Agility trees are leveled by simply being involved in the appropriate activity. All of your progress is saved no matter who or what activity your playing, making co-op a simple and easy thing to snap in and out of with friends.  The types of things to kill are pretty typical for a zombie survival game at this point. The Biters, a slow and shambling aging zombie. The Runners, who are freshly turned and able bodied survivors who still show a disturbing level of humanity as they flinch and beg for mercy as they struggle for control over their minds. The miners, who are huge, lumbering and powerful locals who swing large and devastating pieces of buildings like a hammer. The Frogs, who regurgitate toxin from their heavily infectious insides to hurl at you with disturbing precision. The Hunters, who are player controlled zombies that can actively invade your world at night (Or at any time if you choose), starting a mad dash to kill their nests before you are devoured.  And finally there are the Volatile, who only show up during the night and will pursue you with the speed and ferocity of a starving lion. The only defense against these insane infected is their weakness to UV lighting, something invaluable to you if you dare venture into the city during the dark hours.  With the extended wait for it’s release, this game lives up to it’s initial hype. While I played this game I kept in mind what people knew it would be; A better Dead Island. And even though it has it’s few drawbacks, like a morally confusing protagonist, a map that could have been bigger and an unforgiving experience loss death penalty, it did far more for me then just improve on an old game. This is the fast paced co-op zombie survival horror game I’ve been waiting for.

However, with almost every pro about this game, there's a con, such as: +Awesome story! -Horrible voice acting (for the most part, the majority of main characters are alright though) +AI Humans aren't the best climbers, but throw stuff at you to keep you from cheesing -Their throwing knives also clip through anything between you. The ABSOLUTE most fun I have EVER had gaming has come from Dying Light. I can't stress enough the fun factor in this game, and if you have a few buddies to play with multiply that fun factor by 10,000!   Game play: Hardcore Parkour! It's all about movement and getting the edge on zombies before they surround and kill you. The flow of the game feels somewhat like mirrors edge but perfected and once you get moving and leveling up, you'll never want to stop. The weapons are varied but, you will eventually pick up the same class of weapon with a different name and look so it adds to keep things mixed up a bit and with the added tier of gold weapons you will be left hunting for the best zed smasher! The fighting mechanics are well balanced and absolutley hilarious at times depending on how you choose to end a zombies...well life I guess (I suggest drop kicking off of roofs!)  There are a ton of missions to do but the game can be finished rather quickly if you stick solely to story missions but you will be missing out on a lot of good stuff if you go that route. Their are some slight cons but nothing major to turn you away running. There are a few bugs from time to time like enemies clipping but never will you see constant crashes or anything. I could go on for hours about how great this game is but I think you should play it yourselves to find out. Hope this helps those of you debating buying or not. Totally worth 60+ dollars. Goodnight, and Goodluck!

I have so many STEAM games, that I overlook just how good some of them are. I revisit some of my games, and it is only then that I realize just how good a game is. That's the case with Dying Light. I've had this game since it was first released. I played it a while, and had my attention pulled away by some of my other games. I'm glad I revisited this masterpiece.  There are several side missions for you to do in this big open world. You're free to roam where you want. The play is superb, the running, vaulting and climbing is very fluid. The game looks beautiful. The AI of the zombies is pretty good. The crafting system is deep enough.   Often times you'll be surprised, having one of the undead on top of you with just barely enough time to react. It will all come down to your fight or flight instinct, in several of the situations that occur in this game. You'll need to assess the sitution, and either try to run, or kill.   This is an amazing gaming experience! You can become lost in this scary, and unpredictible world. If you think that the daytime is scary, my God wait till you're away from a safe zone at night! You can find yourself kissing the ground of the safe zones at times, having just escaped from Death in the form of a grotesque humanoid or demonic-looking creature. You and it - looking at one another, seperated only by the razor's edge. You'll realize that you're safe for now, but you'll also quickly realize that you can't hide forever. You'll have to imerse yourself in this nightmare in order to get out alive.   I can't wait to play this through, and then get to The Following. And, when the sequel to this game comes out, look for some record sales.

A solid effort for Techland.

So I will start by saying the parkour system in here is a lot of fun. Makes it incredibly fun(and frustrating at times when you die) to just run around the city. The combat system is also pretty good, not anything incredibly special but the dismemberment is very visceral and satisfying. The general gameplay of this game is great and a lot of fun to play, the story however is not. This game has a lot of features of rpgs(skill trees, loot, etc) but it has non of the great story telling you might associate with rpgs. The story at best was dissappointing and at a lot of times, just plain infuriating to me. It is a sad sign when I think a lot of the side quests are better written than the main story line. There are many problems with the story ranging from trying to force you to have emotional connections with characters you have met 2 to 3 times total, to a mediocre villian on a pedestal. To me it seems they tried to make a villian similiar to vaas from far cry 3, and in my opinion didn't come close to capturing the charm that vaas had.  The few problems I had with gameplay were that after a certain point, your agility level would level a lot slower than your other skill trees, and I feel like they simply needed to boost the amount of agility experience that you got later on in the game to compensate for this. Additionally while most of the game is entirely able to be played in co-op, the finale of the game is not. This was a fact that I did not appreciate at all, don't have the ability to do every other part of the game with your friends, and then force you into a single player mission. I understand why they did it from a design perspective, but they could just have easily done everything in it as co-op and then had a cutscene. Even with all the problems I had with the story that I will not bother to write about, I would still recommend this game as it is a fun time running through the city. It is even more fun if you have some friends to play it with. I would like to see another dying light game, but with a vastly improved story, and perhaps one where you as the character got to make decisions rather than just being on rails.  Overall I enjoyed this game and recommend it, I am giving it an 7.5/10 as the gameplay is just fantastic and overall this should cause the game to be an 8.5+, but thanks to the story it has recieved a lower score as the further i got into the story the less I enjoyed the game.

Let me share my INCREDIBLE first few hours of dying light:  At first the game was a struggle, it took me a while to even be able to freerun through the tutorial course xD  Once I got the hang of it, the gameplay seemed slightly dull and mediocre.... until I got through my first night.  My first night run in Dying Light was THE best experience Ive ever had playing a video game.  Seeking a challenge I had my settings on the highest difficulty with Zombie Invasion on Always.  This was a mistake.  Following the end of the cutscene of your first volatile encounter I ran into three volatiles within 30 seconds of running. Panicking, I ran into the heart of the city. This was also a mistake. There was no light Whatsoever and I walked into a steet, FILLED with infected, their figures could only be seen as eerie silouettes in the moonlight. I took to the roofs as quickly as possible, so as to use the moonlight to plot a path, My heart pounding in my chest as I could hear the volatiles snarling behind me barely missing me as I scrambled onto the roofs. There must have been 5+ volatiles chasing me, I had one medkit left, and I didnt pack any diapers.  I ran like never before. Addrenaline coursing through me, I ran at top speed, never missing a step. I could almost feel the cool night air running through my hair. But the volatiles are relentless. I could hear their snarling and breathing getting louder and louder as they slowly caught up to me. I missed a precision jump (mechanics for which are done perfectly in the game ) and plummeted into the dark abyss of the streets below.  I kept running, it was all I could do, taking sharp turns in alleyways and vaulting the smaller obstacles, as packs of zombies clawed at me, tugging my shirt, slowing me down and damaging me where they could. Despite slowing down to use my final medkit I was gaining ground. Laughing at the insanity that is night running.  Until I hit a dead end.  In a moment of brilliance, I remembered the Light. The UV flashlight, Spikes words echoing in my mind 'If you run into one of those volatiles give them a blast of UV light'. I spun around and shined the light directly in the face of a volatile, making full eye contact with one of the grotesque husks of a being that had been chasing me, before it recoiled from the light. The sight of it still haunts me to this day. I was not bothered by its rotting flesh or jagged teeth, but rather the look in its bloodshot eyes. It almost looked ...not happy, but content as if it somehow knew my situation was hopeless.  Time seemed to slow down as I kicked the creature in its exposed ribcage, frantically searching for a way out. There it was. A single perfect ramp angling toward an adjacent roof. Without hesitation I pushed past the creature as 2 more arrived to seal the alleyway, each hitting me in turn. With 17HP I somehow slipped between them, ran up the ramp and back onto the moonlit rooftops. I could hear my own panting in tune with Kranes as we ran towards the MASSIVE suspension bridge.  There must have been hundreds of zombies on that bridge. I ran, jumping car to car, knowing that with one wrong step, I would surely perish. I kept running, night blind. My path barely visible in the low flames of wrecked cars. I tripped and scrambled, screamed and prayed, desperately trying to get off that god forsaken bridge. I ran and ran until I reached the center of the bridge, which had been destroyed, presumably in order to quarantine the area. There was no way out, in front there was nothing but a hole in the bridge, looming what seemed like a thousand meters over pitch black water. To my rear the volatiles had caught up with me, now within 20 meters. I took one last look at the murky black water and jumped. I saw the distant UV lights of a settlement when I finally surfaced and began the long swim back.   I managed to get back to the tower that night, counting my blessings. For I doubt many others could've survived that run.   10/10 I've never been so terrified and exhilirated. Gameplay at higher levels becomes even more fun and faced pace. Skill trees are creative and progressive. Looting system is a mix of skyrim (lockpicking), farcry (body animations) and thief (object animations), which is fantastic. (you really feel pressed for time lockpicking while firecrackers etc are distracting them and you can be hurt grabbing objects encouraging grab and gtfo style looting. Story so far is MUCH better than anticipated. Graphics are AMAZING (If you get motion sick, turn off depth of field and motion blur :))  Fantastic Game, would buy again.  If anyone reads all of this and wants to go on a night run with me, send me a message. I cant wait to try multiplayer.

Since Dying Lights initial announcement many years ago, I have always been looking forward to this game. As a big fan of the dead island series, I knew that I would love this game when it finally came out. After a few years followed with one or two delays, I can happily say this game was worth the wait.   Whilst it's launch was a little choppy in some areas, mainly regarding the multiplayer in my personal experience, for the most part it has been very smooth and it's fair to say that it has had a much more sucessful launch than that of other games recently. It only took me 5 minutes of tweaking a few settings to get a performance that I considered acceptable to play with, with my system just over recommended specs I certainly have smooth performance, with the exception of a few FPS drops here and there and a little video stuttering, however it doesn't really remain much of an issue.  If you were a fan of the dead island franchise as well as Mirrors Edge, chances are you will quickly fall in love with this game, it's combining the two as well as adding more content. It may look like very similar gameplay to that of Dead Island, however I felt that when playing the fluency of the parkour system, the setting, the plot and the story, characters and overall content just made the game feel so much more dynamic and direct with the player. In addition, the day/night cycle is incredible. Firstly, ignore anyone that says it's fixed. It's not, the cycle is 100% dynamic, some quests (the prologue) just set it to night or such to introduce the setting. But once your out of the prologue, it's 100% dynamic. Me and my friend at first thought night was just sort of a little gimicky selling point, it was only until we were on a mission collecting chocolates for some guy that we were warned night was coming, and when it did we were gone pretty quickly. Do not take the night cycle as a gimick, it's very unique, works very well and adds so much more the game. You don't have to play through it, you can skip it (sleep). However, i advise you try playing through night, through it's encoruagement of double xp and the changes you are forced to undertake to simply survive. You cannot go all out, you will fail and die almost every time. You must plan around the infected to achieve anything, stay hidden, use UV wisely and such. It feels like an entirly different game at times during the night.  Overall, well I don't think I have enjoyed the launch of a game so much in the past 2 or 3 so years, with the last being Far Cry 3. For a zombie game, Dying Light is a surprisingly fun experience that trumps its predecessor: Dead Island.  Dying Light introduces parkour into a zombie apocalypse, and it makes the rpg experience so much fun. The animations are smooth and transition without hitches, to where you can go from running on rooftops to drop kicking zombies into spiked traps, to using the heads of the infected as a means of transportation. After a point in the game, you acquire a grappling hook, which adds an element of verticality to the game, and greatly speeds up the action in the game,   The melee system from Dead Island has been cleaned up, and feels great. The upgrade skills you get can give you unique options to kill zombies other than 'wackig with bat'  The graphics are great, with amazing visual and audio feedback, zombies *feel fun* to cut and slice, and the elemental effects are amazingly visceral. The game runs pretty well, even on lower end machines.  The story is cliche and forgettable with the cast of zombie survivor tropes, and a bunch of plot holes. Fortunatly, there are plenty of side quests and activities that can increase your playtime.  Dying Light's gimmick is that you can play either in the daytime or nighttime, and these have different playstyles. During the day, you get to enjoy Harran in all its beauty. However in the night, zombies become more active and dangerous, creating a much more intense experience.   I do have some gripes especially with some of the mobs (exploding zombies in particular), which seemed to be placed in trolly locations and stop the zombie mayhem with insta-kill mechanics. Some of the later side quest these jerks are placed in closets, and will insta-kill you when you are trying to finish a quest.  Overall, Dying Light is the best zombie-action game on the market and worth checking out.  Reccomendede

TLDR: 7/10   Note: This brief review is only for the single player aspect of the game, as I never tried and therefor cannot comment on the multiplayer portion.  Dying Light is one of those rare games that delivers on the promises it made. While this is an excellent plus, it is tempered by the fact that Dying Light didn't promise much more than 'Roof-top, running from zombies (Parkour system) & a differing level of challenge between day and night.  The game is overall well put together, and is a solid purchase, I have only two complaints, which make up the majority of my negatives.  1 - Long breaks in the narrative, especially the last 10 or so hours. I love story, it is for me the primary aspect I look for in a game. While Dying light has a decent story, which seems to have been stretched from a 10 hour narrative to a 20 hour one.  2 - The second issue, is really a case of nit picking. There is an item that you get much later in the game. I won't spoil it, but this item fundamentally changes the way you can navigate and avoid zombies. Access to this item should have happened way sooner than the last few missions.  This is a long game for its type, I'm a slow player and the story took me almost 30 hours. Anyone looking to get dollar value from an AAA title can do a lot worse than Dying Light

I've put 67 hours (as of this writing) into this game, and I've won it twice. Dying Light is a step above the common zombie game due to a few factors:  - Parkour mechanics - Night/Day cycle - Focus on stealth and silence to avoid more powerful/faster zombies (known as virals)  After 60+ hours and two wins I can say this is definitely a game to keep and a game to explore. There are a lot of little details that might escape your notice the first time around. Parkour challenges, quarantine zones, and awesome rewards in unique and difficult-to-reach places give you a reason to keep looking beyond the linear 'go to the next spot'.  Unlike a lot of zombie games where the focus is never being bit, you start out infected. This lessens the fear factor a bit because now you don't have to worry about infection and zombies become more like rabid animals to be put down. That doesn't mean that you're invulnerable. At night the zombies become stronger and faster, and new types of zombies come out that patrol the streets. Wait out the night in a Safe Zone or take to the rooftops and earn double the experience.  You play the role of Kyle Crane, a GRE operative from Chicago, IL, who has landed in the middle of the Harran quarantine in order to find a stolen file with data on the virus. Along the way you'll make new friends, complete quite a few humerous side quests, and explore two huge, unique zones in your quest to not only find the stolen data but decide just what you want to do with it.  Pros: - Parkour mechanics that are super smooth and fun - Interesting day/night cycle that make you question each quest 'Can I finish this one before it grows dark?' - Hundreds of interesting quests, challenges, quarantine zones, and little tidbits to find - 3-path talent system lends itself to multiple play styles. Fast, 1H melee, 2H smasher, quick and agile stealth, etc.  - A very wide variety of craftable boosters, weapons, and traps for any play style  Cons: - Story is predictable. There was not one twist or turn I didn't forsee. - No choices in the storyline. In the end, it always goes the same way. You have the choice of when you want to do each quest, but the end result is the same.  If you want to try something new in the zombie genre, the game is definitely recommended, if you can get past the predictable story.

This game does everything so damn well.  The movement system is incredibly polished and makes running around the map entertaining rather than tedious. The zombies are really well balanced, there's some that can run/climb but they are generally attracted by sound, the others will come after you if you are nearby but you can easily outrun them.  Starting out in the game is really tough. The game has a skill-based system which means that you have three areas to gain experience in - agility (running/general parkour), power (killing stuff), survival (quests, crafting, not entirely sure). These each have their own skill trees that you use throughout the game to get upgrades. The upgrades are great and definitely worth the time invested in getting them (especially the grappling hook late game).  The story is okay. It's not incredible, but it's still enjoyable. I'm enjoying the quests themselves more than the backstories behind them, which I'm fine with in an action-based game.   The game includes a crafting system which isn't shoved down your throat, Basically while you're running around doing quests you'll run into buildings with crates or toolboxes and you can loot stuff from those, or from zombie corpses, etc. You can then use the loot for crafting things like medkits to weapon upgrades. Blueprints are found throughout the map or rewarded through missions which is pretty cool too.  In terms of difficulty, this game can be easy at some points, but also incredibly intense at other points, especially during the night. I'm not going to go into detail here because I'll be spoiling it. ;) I haven't even gotten into the co-op modes but I'm definitely looking forward to it once some friends start playing.  Onto the most important part to some people - performance. This game runs at a rock solid 60FPS... except for when there's a lot of fire, then it dips to 40ish. I don't know why this is, but I would love for it to get fixed in the future.  All in all, I'm really happy with my purchase. Running around, killing zombies, looting stuff, and getting upgrades is incredibly fun. The map is really well designed and there's many things to do. Lots of replayability. I'd highly recommend this game. If you're still hesitant to buying it, give the demo a try.

Had i written this 10 hours into the game, it would have been one, uninterrupted praise. It still kinda is but later some problems in the story telling emerge.  Pro:  It's a wonderful mixture or Assassons Creed, Far Cry and Mirrors Edge. It has a huge and interesting open world, good fighting system, reasonably dangerous zombies in impressive quantities (hello dayz). And fun tools and abilities to deal with them. Once you skilltrained™ out of the hide-and-run-away phase. And it's not just an action/fighting/parcoury game, with an open world to play in, but very story driven and quite a lot of RPG added, to make it very nteresting and motivating and unique. Which also sets it apart from Far Cry and some of the later Assassins creeds.  Also some of the side quests are quite remarkably in style, emotional storytelling and athmosphere, and an absolute highlight of the game. Like the kindergardener with his wife... don't want to spoil it.  That makes it (for an action game) very special and unique and makes more then up for the small glitches in the main story i'm adressing now.  You could even argue that, if Fallout 4 passes for an RPG, Dying Light does as well or even more.  Con: So what's my problems?  1. It's the tools and drive of the (main)storytelling. Several times during the story script-events, you can not influence, put you in situations you could've easily escaped. For example you're suddenly made to surrender to 2 people with guns, you'd normally kill or beat up in a few moments,  Just to make the following boss fight more difficult and frustrating (completely artificially AND unfairly) than it should be.  It made me so angry, i cheated back at the game at this point :-)  2. Also at times and with no explanation parts of the game mechanics, like grapple hook, the bow or special abilites, are simply... disabled to to make a situation artificially more difficult. That's just bad game design.  3. Towards the end (?),Story and main quests feels AWFULLY strechted out. Feels you're close to the end for FAR too long now.  The thing is: that's completely unnecessary. At this point, the game is far longer already then action games these days usually are. And it gets there in a very good, interesting and motivating way. There would be no shame in closing the story in style to a satisfying end.  Instead they started to turn buildings into labyrinths, let you check 5 instead of 1 or 2 locations for a quest, send you in circles for them.   4. Also i feel that unlike in Far Cry, the stealthy approach, the game kinda offers, doesn't really work, too many psychic enemies, you can't hide from. ___________ It has a online mode, i don't use and therefore can't judge. The times when they got people VAC banned for single player mods are gone, i think. They got rightfully a lot of flak for this BS mechanics. ___________  Still: I edited the review, as it sounded more omplainy than the game deserves. Cause at the bottom line: __________________________________________________________ It's VERY VERY good game for a very long time, just loses it's drive a bit later on. Rather do more side quests then rush though the main story without ever looking left and right, or you miss out badly.  It beats several well known fulll-on RPGs in this area.

I wish i could give this a Neutral rating because there are some parts of this game which really irk me but certainly not enough to give a Negative review.  PROS:   The game is beautiful. It has stunning scenery, great lighting and is well thought out in all 3 dimensions.   The parkour aspect is entertaining especially early-on when you have limited combat options and later-on when you dont feel like fighting because you are on your way from A to B   The side-quests don't feel like McGuffin hunts, they feel like you are actually part of this messed up city   Although the story is predictable in general, it is mostly free flowing and enjoyable.   NEUTRAL:   Fighting is clunky and unintuitive, i understand that this is a specific choice by the Devs to emphasise the parkour aspect but i never felt comfortable with the fighting.   Why does the bow have a range of 10m? The bow must be made of cheap plastic or something!   NEGATIVE:   The major story-line is plagued with boss fights like the infamous ones in Deus Ex: Human Revolution. The Boss fights require you to use almost the opposite aspects of the game (fighting over parkour & avoiding) and it is like you need a completely different mind-set to take them on.   The 'escape levels' are just lame-@rse BS... suddenly you have to run, in the dark, against massively over-matched foes and need to keep dying until you learn the exact route you are supposed to take - god, i wish i could have just space-bar'd my way past these rubbish levels.   After the game is played through the final 'fight' is a series of Quick-time events... are you f#cking kidding me? Did the devs try to shove as many game-mechanics as they could into the campaign just for the hell of it?   The Biggest PRO for me - You regularly had moments where you were genuininely on the edge of your seat as you got stuck in a bad fight or were racing back to a safe house as darkness approached. To keep that level of tension up all the way through the game is pretty impressive and it was enough to entice me to stay and play on through to completion even with the things i did not like about DL The Biggest CON for me - the  insta-deaths  through mistiming jumps, through the Infected suddenly laying into you because of the issues with the combat system. The ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ escape-level insta-deaths because you did not memorise the paths properly from the previous 5 insta-deaths.  I bought the whole series for $20 and am yet to play DL: The Following. I MIGHT replay this game despite its various frustrations and i would have to give it a 6/10. The Great parts are fantastic whilst the problems are just plain annoying and lame.

TLDR: Overall this game get's a 9/10 from me, and I'd recommend it to anyone that enjoys survival-horror games. A truly top-quality production.  Detailed Thoughts:   I honestly didn't know if I was going to find another well-written, polished survival-horror game or series I liked as much as the Dead Space franchise. I've tried a great many and mildly enjoyed most for different reasons, but I just couldn't find anything that fired on all cylinders for me like that. Until I picked up Dying Light.  I can't overpraise this game. It has everything I've always wanted in a zombie game. Great story, amazing graphics, beautifully-designed environment, excellent dialogue, in-depth crafting system, combat that never gets old (for me at least), and an ever-present creeping tension you never quite get used to. A tension that keeps you looking over your shoulder and often turns to raw fear in the middle of a night sequence or when a corroded zombie *pops* and you hear the wail of incoming Virals. Now, I'm no coward. I simply enjoy allowing a horror game's atmosphere to overwhelm me, and this game did that and more. I never play games like these with the lights on, with friends, or without headphones. I do what I can to let the game get the best of me; the way I feel it's meant to be played.  And the parkour. I didn't know I needed this so much until Techland gave it to me. It blends wonderfully into this style of game. When you get all your gadgets and skills unlocked the city becomes your playground and you can pick and choose when you want to fight or preserve your best weapons. Many aspects of it enhance the depth of the combat greatly.  The skill and character progression has an impactful feeling to it. Where you start out beating one zombie to death with 15 swings from a rusted pipe, you'll end with an electric broadsword that beheads 3-4 zombies at a time with one swing. The combat is full of surprising details too. Using an electric weapon while its raining is more effective and will shock an enemy far more often. Or you can douse a tough enemy with flammable liquid and poke them once or twice with a tiny, flame-imbued knife and set them ablaze letting it do all the work. There are guns in the game, but ammo is scarce until you hit The Following expansion. But their use in either setting is exactly as it should be: highly effective but the noise you generate is the cost. Always drawing more attention from Virals, Volatiles, and the lumbering horde.  I won't go into much detail about The Following other than to say that the story was acceptable, but the 'cult' aspect wasn't nearly as creepy or deranged as I imagined it could be. Everything else about the expansion - the new area, new weapons, buggy traversal + combat - all added to the base game in a way that felt different but natural. Very enjoyable with plenty of content.  At a whole I enjoyed this game so much that it is now one of my favorites of all time. One playthrough took me about 38 hours. I loved it so much that I immediately started another. Now I'ved played the base game maybe 4 times and the expansion once, and I fully intend to revisit it once the memory has faded some. If this is a genre you enjoy, then I beg you to give this a try. Thank you for your time if you made it this far.

It may be squalid and zombie-infested, but Dying Light's city of Harran isn't a depressing wasteland – it's a vibrant, ambitious, open-world playground. Here, buildings are for climbing, the undead are there to be destroyed in creative ways, and there's always something interesting to be discovered nearby. It takes a while for that to become clear, though; at first, you might even think Dying Light is really about running scared from mobs of seemingly unconquerable zombies, who can quickly drain your stamina and wear out your improvised weapons. Don't be fooled. Yes, it's a struggle to survive in Dying Light's early hours. Combat is initially clumsy, with the diverse and deadly zombies able to soak up a disturbing amount of punishment before they die for good. Jumping – which is unintuitively mapped to shoulder buttons on consoles – can take a while to get used to. Getting mobbed is usually a death sentence. So is attracting the attention of the much more dangerous things that come out when daytime dynamically gives way to night, at which point the focus shifts to tense stealth — or, if you’re discovered, an adrenaline-pumping sprint for the nearest safe point.  Before long, though, you'll build up a skill set that turns your rotting foes into objects of fun, letting you vault across their shoulders, quickly slice them apart with dramatic slow-motion kills, or trick them into gathering around explosives before blasting them all into the sky. Even nighttime becomes an opportunity to raise skills faster thanks to increased XP gain, rather than a period of sheer terror. It all feels great, too; once you adjust to the controls, Dying Light's first-person parkour becomes natural and fluid, and weaving high-speed paths through its decaying slums and picturesque old-world buildings is so much fun that I almost don't hate the lack of a fast-travel option.  Combat, meanwhile, gets increasingly satisfying, although it never quite loses its awkwardness. Even when expertly shredding zombies with elementally charged tools of death I built myself, strikes are still heavy and clumsy. And while the guns you'll find later can pop heads from a distance, their low rate of fire and zombie-attracting noise makes them more of an occasional quick fix than a game-changing weapon. To Dying Light's credit, though, your adversaries are surprisingly capable; while the rank-and-file Biters are dumb and fun to manipulate, more powerful enemies – like the quick, agile Virals – are formidable close-quarters opponents, ducking your strikes and sidestepping out of your reach while looking for an opening to attack. Hostile bandits are even deadlier, able to dodge and block at close quarters, throw knives from a distance, and use guns and group tactics to kill you if you get overconfident.  That Dying Light's world is so entertaining is important, because it's unexpectedly huge. Finishing the campaign took me more than 34 hours, with a 68 percent completion rate. The story is serviceable enough, focusing on an undercover agent who becomes a savior to infected survivors and a thorn in the side of a maniacal warlord, but the most surprising thing about it might be its lack of surprises. Similar games have primed me to expect shocks and betrayals that will yank the metaphorical rug out from beneath me, and yet apart from a few big twists early on, Dying Light plays it mostly straight, with little nuance and few hidden agendas from its interesting (but underdeveloped) characters and entertainingly cliché villains. In a way it's almost refreshing, even if the end result is nothing special.  A big chunk of my time, though, was spent on detours into side quests, which are where the storytelling really shines. Taking on one of the many requests from random survivors might lead to something ordinary, like a fetch quest – but more often than not, they're multi-part adventures with their own short storylines, which frequently start out as seemingly run-of-the-mill tasks and escalate into something much more lurid and creepy. A search for a missing person, for example, might turn into a hunt for progressively more unsettling clues in a seemingly abandoned apartment building, and a routine rescue mission might turn out to be a trap set by a conniving madman. These are some of Dying Light's most memorable moments, and they make exploring its world even more rewarding.  While it's entirely playable as a single-player game, Dying Light is – like most things – better with friends along. Up to three co-op partners can jump in at any time to help you carve up undead hordes, watch your back while you're picking locks, or pursue campaign missions, and while the online matchmaking is still fairly hit-or-miss on PS4, online sessions are smooth and stable once they get going.  It's also useful to have friends around if your game is invaded through the 'Be the Zombie' mode, which lets a random player jump into your world as a super-powered monster with zipline tendrils and zombie-summoning spit. Playing as said monster is hugely enjoyable, especially after you’ve unlocked some of its grosser attacks, but it feels one-sided unless you're going up against at least two human players.  Other than moderately better visuals, the PC version's biggest leg up on its console counterparts is its customizable keyboard-and-mouse controls. Keeping track of the assorted key functions can be a little trying when things get frantic, but using the space bar to jump still feels more immediately natural than R1 or RB on PS4 or Xbox One. (Gamepads are, of course, supported.) Early on, there were reports that Dying Light would hang before dialogue or cutscenes, but these issues appear to have been patched, and the PC version now mostly runs smoothly for us, with only rare hitching while areas load. There is, however, an occasional issue with some textures popping in at low resolution and sticking that way. The PS4 version has a similar problem, but while it quickly corrects itself, textures that show up blurry on PC tend to stay that way.  Beginning as a furtive, desperate survival-horror experience, Dying Light gradually and gratifyingly evolves into a fast, hyper-violent celebration of vertical freedom and zombie destruction. Its main story is unspectacular, but the memorable side quests and sheer fun of exploring its world do a fantastic job of offsetting that, making Dying Light one of the most engrossing open-world games – zombie-infested or otherwise – I've played in a while

The soundtrack is amazing, enhancing the atmosphere to an even higher point.   The game has quite a bit of replay value, and has the qualities of many games. The zombie aspect of Dead Island (though done much better), the parkour of Assassin's Creed with the first person twist, and the open world factor of Far Cry.  The game does have its flaws however. You will likely need a decent rig to play the game above mid-settings (though the game is still beautiful this way). There are also several bugs, though none harmed my gaming experience.  Overall, I'd give it a 9.5/10.

This game feels much like Dead Island & Riptide, but at the same time it's completely different. While the previous two games are a hack & slash fest, Dying Light forces you to be more cautious. My first night encounter almost left me ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ my pants. I've made it to a drop when suddenly it got all dark. And I mean really dark... I knew I didn't have much time. I had to get to a safe house. Then it spots me. This big ugly crazy zombie beast. I start running, but I can't see where I'm going. I run and jump and I hear the creature right behind me. I'm afraid to look back and keep going, completely disorientated. Then I try to climb on a rooftop when it bites me... I still manage to get on the rooftop and turn around. I'm surrounded... A pack of menacing zombies approach and climb on the rooftop. I swing at them with my electrical pipe and sparks fly all over the place. But I knew a was in real trouble... While panicking I tried to grab my UV flashlight, but they were too fast. I got bitten and thrown on the ground and bitten again and again. GAME OVER... After that I quit the game. I needed a breather. So yeah, this is totally NOT like Dead Island.
