Spider-man meets Mirror's Edge. Apperently you arrive in a poorly written story as a hired gun to do the dirty work for them. You dont even need to play this game for 10 min before you know something fishy is going on with the people he works for. The story is really boring and such a cliché.  What i disliked about the game:  - Noise attracts super zombies, regardless of where you are. Apparently they can hear a gun shot from EVERYWHERE!  - Water, blood, sun and all other annyoing effects blur your vision waaaaaaa(add more a's)aaaaay to much. Half the time you just wait for it to go away so you can see again. (Why make such an annyoing effect and then make so much content in a sewer?)  - The seizures, its so frustrating, not because you feel the agony, but because its just removing any way of playing when he's whimping about. We get it, he's turning, but come on, especially after he says 'this can't be happening now', for the 10th time.  - I think theres around 10 different types of zombies, pretty mundane towards the end.  - Way to much time spent in water, why would you do that when the swimming is terrible.  - The melee combat was cool at first, but after you behead a zombie for the 50th time, its not that interesting anymore (Also since its only the same type of zombies that you can behead).  - Weapons; Guns is just frustrating since it attracts super zombies without a question. Why is there no silencers? I see military equipment all over the place, but not 1 has a silencer. Reparing of weapons just leaves you to being carefull instead of careless (I cant use this badass weapon i just made as much as i wanted, because it will break eventually) which is really annyoing.  - Exploding zombies gets boring really quick, since its often just unavoidable.  - QTE bosses is the worst in a fps game, really, if i wanted to press A, S, D or W when you told me, i'd be playing a kids game instead.  - The annyoing Dead Island, FarCry and now Dying Light crafting system, it doesnt offer anything fun, that i have to craft my own baseball bat with nails in it, its a fun gimmick, but also completely irrelevant since most weapons you pick up is better or just not worth the hazzle. If you want to make the player get excited about crafting, make it more interesting or just leave it out.  - The sleeping (I can sleep whenever i want, why make such a fuss about it being night?)  - Weird AI (Ie. 3 dudes is guarding a npc, you kill off 2 of them without the 3rd one even seeing you, but you cant talk to the npc before the 3rd guard is dead)  - The map seems big at first, but its not, its actually kind of limited. Also very repetative surroundings, houses, zombies, safe houses etc.   What i like about the game:  - The fast paced running (Not untill later in the game though), which was really missed in the start of the game. I understand that the character evolves throughout the game, but one would thing that running is something every soldier is trained to do well.  - The slowmotion when you cut of limbs (Could have been way more variations)  - Weapon upgrades (Not the crafting part) is a cool gimmick, they could put a lot more work into it though.  - Side missions (Without it, the game would be very short)  - Co-op is always a huge plus.  - The hook.  - Parkour is always fun, but also a bit crazy at times, to see what he can hang onto as long as you hold space.   Summary:  You can predict anything that will happen in this game, since its so cliché. You know what kind of zombies there will be (Slow ones, exploding ones, runners, huge ones etc.), theres a villan (who almost wins duh), the plot twists, the awkward forced feelings about some random woman who you maybe have 5-8 cutscenes with and then he just falls head over heels for her (i mean come on, make some effort in the character building).  All in all, dont waste your money on this if you already tried games like Far Cry, dead island and assassins creed. It feels like a mix of a lot of games put into one. Also, the game starts out slow, which is understandable, but it also means that when you start to become more agile, strong and fast, the game slowly becomes boring and repetative, which is a shame. This is just my personal oppinion, you dont have to agree at all, but i was just dissapointed with it. Theres absolutely nothing new in this game and i wish the creators were a bit more creative, instead of trying to take good working things out of other games and fitting them into theirs only.

This game is just Dead Island with a different name, exact gameplay. Nothing new, nothing fresh, and it is loaded with bugs. They are charging way too much for the game, they hardly did anything to their Dead Island engine that they may as well have called this dead island 4 or whatever ridiculous number they're on. The story is so weak the only reason you will play is to hang out with a friend for co-op. That's what I did... the intro and the ending can not be co-op... I don't know why, it seems like the developers have a problem with co-op and they don't think the whole game should be played together.   I don't know why games are so clueless when it comes to co-op, but they really dropped the ball on this one. It's not finished, or should I say they just don't seem to care about their own game? I would stab myself in the eyes if I had to play this solo... I can't recommend this game for anyone unless it's about 10$ and you have a friend who is bored enough to pay 10$ as well.  Climbing buildings sucks bad, good luck doing it consistently. Once you get the grappling hook, if you can stand the game that long, it's a little more tolerable but even that barely works right.   Shooting guns is a chore, I doubt anyone would bother.   Weapons just break... I don't really care about realism in games as long as it follows the rules of the world, but a crowbar breaking? Kind of hard to believe even though every weapon in the game breaks. I mean I realize this is how china makes things for the USA, but I didn't expect it to be in dying light. What's the point?? All it does is annoy you as a gamer.   Practically non-existent story, if anyone actually follows this crap I feel sorry for them. Dialogue is probably written by teenagers, just tacky, boring. It's a simple over used plot in the zombie universe. I would expect more from 'artists' but certainly feels like a cash grab.   Thoughtless skill tree, and why is there a skill tree anyway? What lame ♥♥♥ purpose does it serve? Just to find out the abilities you could have had at the start would have made the game so much more interesting from the get go, instead they barely even plan it out so you're max at the end of the game. You can unlock every single ability, so why have a dumb skill tree? Makes no sense. Maybe if they made the abilities available, except you just get better at them as the game goes on, but no... I don't expect anything new and different from developers.   The game is overall boring and weak, there is no emotion, no thought... it could have been so much more and they just don't care, and they didn't even improve on the Dead Island series. It's just another near identical cliche game from another weak thoughtless developer.

While the single player campaign can be described as mediocre at best when compared to Dead Island's expansive Resort and City of Morseby maps and the various others. My issue is with the 'Be The Zombie' PvP mode. Below are the issues that make playing as a Night Hunter not only terribly difficult but also no fun what so ever.  1: You can't see four feet in front of you. One would think that a zombie would have enhanced night vision; not in DL! Take the city at night and basicaly give it a photo negetive color scheme and thats your 'zombie-vision' if this is what they see no wonder they walk off ledges and trip down stairs.  2: Survivors have an infinite use, instant rercharge, infinite range UV flashlight. Not only can human players use this as many times and for as long as they want your energy drains instantly and the effective range is well over 600 yards roughly. Which turns this flashlight into a medium range F.U. add to that when your energy drains you can't jump, run, or use your tendril making you an easy kill with no way to escape.  3: Your attacks don't do sh!t. Human players get to keep all their over powered (and probably hacked) weapons plus items and gear and all you start with is a howl (which serves ONLY to give your position away) and a weak @ss claw attack that barely scratches a human. Before you say it, yes I am aware of the howl's ability to reveal humans but all you've succeded in doing is finding him but he knows where you are too so it's more of a liability than an advantage.  4: It's four against one. Ok how is this even REMOTELY fair? Not only do you have four human players to contend with but you also have to protect nests on top of that. Nests that are in horrible locations some of which make them un-defendable (any nests located in or under things). This is my biggest problem. We all know that even one human survivor with half a brain can easily hold their own with all the un-fair advantages I listed but add in even one other person and it becomes impossible. They will never split up they'll cover each other and you as the lone zombie won't have a snowball's chance.  Basically I wasted my money for a lack luster single-player and a pathetic excuse for a multiplayer that not only rips off Left 4 Dead (which actually gives the infected a small chance of winning) but also makes it no fun at all (unless your a human, you cheat, or both).  In short: THANKS FOR NOTHING TECHLAND! ANOTHER WINNER!

Let's go ahead and get this out of the way: Intel Core i7 3770K @ 3.50GHz 16.0GB Dual-Channel DDR3 @ 686MHz XFX Radeon R9 295X2  This game runs like utter garbage in it's current state. I have never been more disappointed in a purchase than I am with Dying Light. Other than the obvious PC from Console Port inventory system, the issues with performance on PC is just...terrible. Shame on the developer for releasing this in such a broken and unplayable state.  Just to be clear - this game ran great in the first little section of the tower. But right away things become very annoying very fast - such as the overblown film grain and chromatic abberation. The latter makes this game extremely blurry, distorted, and difficult to make out any details. Once you step outside the tower and into the game, you can expect your FPS to drop, and drop, and drop. Stare at the ground and you'll be fine, but if you want to actually play the game, be prepared to play in the 20 - 30 FPS range.  Also, it's 'additional effects' ie depth of field would have been nicely promoted had there had been a large disclaimer: WARNING - This game designed to be ran by NVidia powered GPUs only.   As for the gameplay - I honestly couldn't tell you. After a few minutes of attempting to fight zombies at extremely low FPS, exiting, adjusting effects, tweaks, and trying an external tweaking tool, I have finally given up on this title.  Techland - You dropped the ball for PC gamers. Buyers beware, this is not a game worth playing right now.

*spoilers follow*  Feels like an upgraded and greatly improved Dead Island. Looks better, combat is better, the parkour feels pretty good - not quite up there with Mirrors Edge, but very workable.   The story was very ordinary, evil government agencies trying to use a zombie virus as a weapon, protagonist agent going Dances with Wolves native with the survivors inside the quarantine zone. Etcetera etcetera et bloody cetera. I guess original storytelling isn't really something I should expect in videogames and so it was good enough.Anyway, the game works quite well, and is enjoyable to play. The night time super-zombies are sufficiently frightening until you get crazy good weaponry, the missions get a bit repetitive but I mostly enjoyed it.   That is until they threw away any appreciation I had with the finale. They threw away my good will with a giant finger raised to everyone that learned and enjoyed the mechanics with a piece of crap QTE bossfight.   Not only QTE, but a lying junk QTE which flashes up letters on the screen as if I know instinctively which finger is on D (they're just up down left and right to me!) and doesn't give you enough time to respond until you've failed and repeated it enough times to learn the sequence like a Simon Says game and ignores your input half the time anyway, extending the amount of retries.  So no, I don't recommend the game, if only because the payoff is an insult to gamers. Go play Dead Island if you insist on supporting this developer - at least its finale used the in game combat mechanics.

Pros: atmopshere- techland finally achieved the atmospheric vibe the dead island games never quite delivered on. There's a healthy amount of fear in every combat situation. you know 2 zombies is a challenge, 4 is an issue and 8 is overwhelming. Then when night falls bravery is for fools. I never really felt the need to get to a safe place after the first hour of any dead island playthrough, The ones that come out at night in this are.no.joke. you will die.  Looks quite nice- when (and i stress when)you're not thermal throttling down to 17 fps, its quite decent looking. the enviroment is beautiful yet rough around the edges in a positive way.(at the time of this amd platforms are not playing super smooth but im sure it will be patched and i can crank back up to high visuals)  The Drop kicks- Yea. If you've played it. you get what i mean by this. the first time you drop kick a zombie off a building.... kool-aid man  Cons: free running system- After being delayed almost a year, the free running works, but it still feels sloppy at times. in such a hostile game,turns into a real big issue.  Level bars- yes the strength of the atmosphere is also a weakness. yes i think from a visual prespective of removing the arcade-like level bars that were in the dead island games does A-LOT for immersion, but as you play deeper into the game is causes great confusion. you go from weapons that do 20 damage to 200 damage and you can't in your heart of hearts always admit you can tell the difference. there's maybe 6-8 zombie templates you see most often. on the off chance you'll get two side by side. one takes one hit to the head and dies. the other one takes 14 hits and keeps getting up. there's no visual que as to why. and when youre making fast twitch descions like do i climb this or that? do i fight or run? it really makes you feel cheated when damage seems to be so randomized.   The Haystack Jump- the blue trash bags you jump into. yes it's a cool idea as far as fitting into the way the game plays with the free running. but they're a mess. i get it not locking into them like in assassin's creed makes it more threatening and dangerous but also it makes it hard to trust and/or use. sometimes you see two dumpsters.the blue bags dont appear from the certain angle you happen to be at so you have to guess (once again after some perfomance patches i exspect this will be mostly cleared up from a visual settings stand point) which almost always results in death. worse yet often, and yes 4 players in one game and it's happened to all of us many times, you land on the bags but they don't cushion your fall and you die. so yes atmospherically not locking you into a dive is cool. but the execution is so untrustable that you're better off not risking it  losing xp- when you die you lose survivor points.that sucks but once again it lends to the atmopshere of the game by making you actually fear death. unfortunately you're going to die alot from clunky game actions. i dare say equal or more often than playing flat out irresponible. for example in co-op we were spawned in a bad area of the game after dying.somehow it had shift a few hours to total darkness,we got murdered. respawned in safe zone across the map, but the night zombies were sitting at the door so we couldn't leave without dying. so we broke up the co-op game.spawned me in my single player game, at night, and you guessed it! surrounded by zombies. died. it's frustrating system when the game has the table on tilt. also why does it takes xp instead of currency? becuase the currency system is pretty much useless after $2000. all you need to buy is medkits.  no fast travel or vehicles-  sometimes you die at night just meters away from a mission objective and it sends you across the map.like...great....thanks....let's try that again in 15 minutes  gameplay in general- at first i was like wow! this game. but each hour has shown cracks and leaks and fractures. and to be honest the story is tacky. Your character volunteers for everything. the man can't say no! he's lifeless. there's a tower with the last 30 people left alive in it and they didn't notice a guy on the roof was selling drugs!!! the loot is unrewarding and shallow. and the combat just goes AWOL at times. you can't hit a zombie with a baseball bat but it has enough reach to smack you. it's repetitive. very. but worst of all the game just seems to turn on you at times. with everything i listed above all at once. even weirder the game plays fine untill you just hit a 20 minute skid where the game just goes from difficulty and skill to being flat out against you.   final answer:  All in all the art, world, and feel of this game is worth the ticket of admission. There's alot to like. but it's frustrating at times. not in a ninja guidan or megaman way. but in a flat out 'why can i suddenly not hit anything/ why does a 10 foot drop take all my health/ why does hitting the slide button stop me dead/ why does everything i normally do suddenly not work' kind of way, and the worst sin of all....it's a little boring. beautiful, dangerous, but boring. and its because of this i can't recommend this game. maybe with some a.i. tweaks and some patches that i know will be coming in the following weeks and months it will be much less frustrating. but i've went to bed unhappy two nights in a row now. this game was so close to great, really. there's alot of talent put into this game.

Dying Light: a disappointment  After playing Dying Light for 13 hours, I have decided to set it aside. Normally, I am motivated to play a campaign from beginning to end. My main motivation now for this game is that I just paid $45 for it, and I should try to get some enjoyment out of it. But alas, I’m done. There are very few games where I just bailed out before the end. Recently, I stopped playing Alien: Isolation – but that was not because it was bad. I stopped playing Alien: Isolation because it was too good – too freakin’ scary. It was an excellent game that scared the bejesus out of me. But Dying Light is another story.  I had wanted to play this game since its release several months ago, but I waited (as I usually do) for it to go on sale – which happened this weekend. The game has amazing promise. A very large cityscape that I am free to explore… if you could call sprinting and scampering over rooftops, exploring – which it really isn’t. And you really need to keep up the speed when traveling through town, because zombies are ever-present. Still, the city and associated landscape are beautifully done. The parkours mechanic is nicely implemented, and I think it is the most enjoyable and satisfying part of the game. Nearly every wall and roof overhang is climbable. Works nearly flawlessly. I soon developed a high degree of confidence about navigating through the city by using this reliable parkours method.  There are two major problems with this game that rapidly drained my enthusiasm for it. I tried to “man-up” and try harder. But I finally threw in the towel. Dying Light was a surprising and sad disappointment for me.  Problem No. 1: Medkits. As I progressed deeper into the campaign and started leveling up, the necessity for medkits increased significantly. Ultimately, my main activity was reduced to searching for the materials needed to fabricate medkits, namely alcohol and gauze. The alcohol was fairly abundant, but the gauze was exceptionally rare. So, side missions and the main campaign had to be postponed, and the game became a grind of seeking out materials for making medkits. People who enjoy the “survivor” style of gameplay will love this game. I don’t. I love zombie games because I like killing zombies in the most brutal and deformative ways possible. But because of the shortage of medkit materials, there is a disincentive to go near zombies. This despite that in order to complete missions, there is no way to avoid zombies. Which leads me to problem no. 2.  Problem No. 2: Weapon repair limitations. The best way to collect good weapons is by killing the antagonist’s guards who you find on patrol in the city. Problem; these are dangerous encounters that suck medkits. Crazier problem, the weapons have a repair limit. This wouldn’t be so bad if the weapons lasted a decent amount of time, but they don’t. A seemingly durable object like a brick hammer has about 30 strikes in it before you need to repair it. Early in the game, a weapon can be repaired a maximum of three times. Afterwards, it cannot be repaired and becomes essentially useless. This leads to the next grind – constantly searching for new weapons to replace tired old weapons. This is especially a waste if the weapon had been modified (which consumes resources) or upgraded (which depletes the one-use upgrade resource).  Both of these “challenges” create an incentive to avoid the main campaign or any side missions because they could involve encounters with zombies which, in turn, will jeopardize miniscule medkit supplies, and which could damage the melee weapons that took so long to find and modify. In other words, it’s a zombie game in which you dare not try to kill zombies.  An internet search for “Dying Light medkits” reveals several links showing how players can harvest an unending supply of medkits and medkit materials by climbing a bridge tower and zip-lining across the gap to an isolated section of the bridge. Although this exploit can solve the problem with medkit shortages, such extraordinary measures shouldn’t be necessary. Besides, they cheapen the game experience.  The medkit fiasco and irreparable weapons policy, unfortunately, are the most “original” aspects to the game. Otherwise, Dying Light is a mashup of Mirror’s Edge (the parkours transits), Dead Island (the zombies and weapons), and Far Cry 3 and 4 (the comm towers; and the psychopathic antagonist) – which sounds like a winning combination. But it wasn’t for me. I don’t need the story to be original. I mean there are only about 30 stories that can be told. The key is the “telling” of the story. We crave that an original and imaginative style be used to communicate the essence of a story we all know so well – but in new and different ways. Ironically, In Dying Light, I have become conditioned not to care about the story because I’m afraid I’ll die due to lack of medkits, and I’m afraid that my precious weapons will soon become irreparable and useless. So, instead of campaigning as a fearless warrior, I have been reduced to a cautious curator. For me, what could have been an interesting, progressive and satisfying zombie-infested campaign sadly regressed into a beautiful and gigantic survival arena.  For the record, I am listing zombie games that I have thoroughly enjoyed: Left 4 Dead Left 4 Dead 2 The Walking Dead Dead Island Dead Island Riptide

Dying Light - I am currently at a 42% game completion within 27 hours of play time. I feel that there is no need to continue beyond this point. Reasons being varied, but mainly concerning with the engagment of the story element.  The story is very cliche and shoehorned in. The AngryJoeShow review details what I've expirenced so far; characters that you will never care for and dialogue that is mere drivel, nor compelling. The antagonist, the villian to our hero, is nothing more than a local mob boss with little to no back story or interesting behavioral characteristics such as in other games like FarCry 3's Voss or FarCry 4's King Min. He's just a bland thug. The dialogue of the main character also is problematic as he seems far too melodramatic during a crisis and sometimes merely annoying in others. The player doesn't really have any envolvment with the fates of other characters they encounter, either to be met with an untimely death in a cutscene or killed off screen.  Besides that, it's just another zombie game from a fragmented team that thought they could bring a more 'mature story' from Dead Island. What colminated was an uninteresting set of characters that will soon be forgotten after their fates are met.  Gameplay, however, is satisfying. The athletic movement of the protagonists and plenty of skillset upgrades make for a enternaining romp through a zombie infested foreign city. The por kour system brings speed and a sense of power when in full motion. There are many types of weapons to acquire, either by purchasing them, crafting them, or finding rare ones in hidden areas of the city. They make for the most satisfying gorefest when confronted by the different enemy types.  The night and day cycles within the game give a refreshing expireince and difficulties as zombies and super zombies span the darkness of the night, while the day time is filled with the mundane zombie and many human theives, thus, and henchmen of the alleged villian.   The zombie enemies are varied as you progress in the game or wait until dark for the more powerful and faster super zombies. Though, incountering some of the so called 'boss' monsters can be accompanied with familiar troupes that long time gamers are so use to and easily overcome these obstacles. QTE events ruin some very important story line aspects, such as the final battle.  All in all, Dying Light has great game play that is mired by an uninteresting story and cast of characters. I do not currently recommned this games until it falls in price. This would be worthwhile at a cheaper pricepoint, but the unsatisfactory conclusion leaves little room for signle player replayability, where Co-op may give a bit more longevity.

This review contains spoilers. TL;DR version is at the bottom.  Dying Light is a first-person hack-and-slash / shooter zombie action game set in the fictional city of Harran (implied to be somewhere near or within the nation of Turkey) where you play as a humanitarian aid organization agent named Kyle Crane, tasked with air-dropping into the zombie-infested, quarantined city to find a rogue politician-turned-dictator who possesses a sensitive file that Crane's superiors order to recover.  What sets this game apart from the rest of the ever-growing cliché zombie game pile, and the feature that everyone recognizes Dying Light for, is the parkour system. Nearly every ledge, building, surface, wall etc. can be freely jumped onto / grabbed onto / climbed on to continue moving fluidly and without stopping. The main method of travelling the open world is running on foot, and the parkour system in general is surprisingly well-done. The freedom of movement allows the player to see things such as buildings, concrete walls, and abandoned vehicles as something more than what they actually are. Instead of a game like Skyrim or Grand Theft Auto V where these things would simply be obstacles, Dying Light instead trains the player to see them as assets to assist them in evading the zombie horde, creating a very extreme example of 'The Floor is Lava' game, except that the penalty for touching the floor in this game can actually be just as bad as touching actual lava in some situations. Ask anyone about Dying Light, and I guarantee you that the parkour is the highest point of the game the majority of the time.  But despite the game's strength that sets it apart from other zombie games, the problem that severely ruins the game as a whole is that it has no focus.  I'll explain.  The main problems with Dying Light come from several different sources: It tries to take itself way too seriously for what it is, it tries to incorporate way too many unnecessary elements, and yet at the same time, it's afraid to take creative risks and tries to play everything safely.  People can and will summarize Dying Light as 'parkour with zombies,' and that description by itself without context honestly sounds like something that's equal parts silly, entertaining, and hardcore, all mixed into one awesome package. Instead, the game tries to be 'epic' with an 'intense storyline' as advertised on the store page with what is possibly one of the most poorly-written, clichéd, melodramatic storylines I've seen in a video game this year. The vast majority of the voice-acting in the game is God-awful for a triple-A title, failing to convince the audience of the emotion that the scene tries to evoke whether it be panic, anger, or sorrow. This is especially apparent when the subtitles are turned on, where some words are written completely in capital letters while the voice is only marginally more stressed. There are even some parts where the protagonist Kyle Crane, whose voice-acting is actually bearable, ends up coming off as whiny and obnoxious when scenes clearly intended him to come off as dramatic and defiant.   In addition, none of the characters in the story do anything that make the audience care for them, even though the game clearly wants you to feel bad when the Young-and-Naive-Character gets infected by zombies or when the Fiery-Female-Character-With-an-Attitude sacrifices her life to prevent you from turning into a zombie. These are meant to be devastating moments in the game, emotional punches towards the protagonist whose character is supposed to be someone who deeply cares for people in need, but ten or twenty minutes later, instead of being traumatized, Crane's voice and demeanor goes completely back to normal like it was just a minor inconvenience, and even starts cracking jokes and sarcasm during one of the later segments in the game involving an extremely tall radio tower to prevent a military carpet-bombing. If this is supposed to be an emotional roller coaster, I must be in the little kids' area of the amusement park.  Speaking of which, let's talk about pacing. The nature of parkour, both in real life and in various media, is meant to be fast-paced. The definition of 'parkour' is to move along a route in the fastest and most efficient way possible. Thus, a game that features parkour as a main mechanic is expected to be relatively fast-paced, especially when the game is in a first-person perspective like Mirror's Edge. And yet, Dying Light just can't seem to make up its mind on the pacing of the gameplay with some of its design choices. Looting materials and weapons is near-instantaneous, and the control returns to the player very quickly after the action is performed, which compliments the fast nature of parkour.  But then, the game insists on including elements that completely break the flow of the game. The melee combat, especially in the early parts of the game, is excessively clumsy and doesn't blend with the parkour element, slowing the player to walking speed and turning the game into aiming blows to the head. Human enemies are the absolute worst offenders of this due to being able to randomly block melee attacks without warning, turning a game about running into a dodge-and-swing-randomly-fest in the early game when the player doesn't have access to ways around it other than 'wait for the enemy to swing first.'  Compare the combat in this game to the combat in Mirror's Edge and you can see that the difference is night and day. The combat and movement in Mirror's Edge are blended together almost seamlessly: One of the developers even states that 'When she [Faith] does hit, she hits quick, fast, hard, and then moves on.' I'm not saying Crane should flip enemies like Bruce Lee, but it's a much better alternative than getting locked into a Mexican standoff.  But the absolute biggest case of mechanics breaking the flow of the game is, believe it or not, containers. The vast majority of the loot is kept in containers, and every single time the player interacts with, Crane goes through an entire animation of bending down and clicking the latches and / or lifting the lid open. Even while underwater, Crane has to slowly lift the lid open despite holding his breath. Is that really necessary? Who actually cares about seeing hands reaching down and lifting a lid open? Did people demand that this was to be in the game? It only gets worse when the majority of these containers are locked, and thus the game forces you into a lockpicking 'minigame' that was blatantly taken from Skyrim, minus the perks that made it less of a pain. It is an absolute shame that a game that boasts parkour and freedom of movement forces you to bend down in a specific spot (the game actually shifts the player to a specific position relative to the interacted container) to fiddle with locks and slowly open a container like there wasn't a zombie apocalypse happening.  Combine all this with an avoidable day and night cycle, repetitive side-quests to fill the game. random collect-a-thons / easter eggs for funsies, and a bad crafting system, and it becomes painfully obvious that Techland wanted to incorporate as much content as possible for the sake of being a big-budget triple-A video game title. There was a significant amount of potential, but instead of focusing building upon that strength, Dying Light ends up trying to build a game from elements of other games that were successful without taking into consideration if these elements would fit in with the flow that the core mechanic provides. The part the stings the most about all of this is that Dying Light could have become something completely unique, fresh, and most importantly, fun, in a genre that's gone beyond stale. But instead of 'THE Zombie Parkour Game,' Dying Light ends up being 'Yet another zombie game, but hey, at least there's some parkour in here.'   TL;DR: 5/10. Painfully mediocre for a $60 game.

Visually it's great. I am not a fan of controls, though: I believe it's not really convenient to run always holding left stick (I use gamepad) and using RB instead of A to jump. Now... Comparison with Dead Island. There is actually one main difference between the two: level of seriousness. Dying Light takes a realistic-ish approach. Whole atmosphere is made to make it feel as real as possible: zombies are few compared to Dead Island, they are a bit more sluggish, but yet more bulky, you can feel their weight when hitting them. The colors are more grey, making the world look sterile and lonely, while Dead Island was bright, reminding you, that a few hours back it was brimming with life. You also get into zombie fighting here, when other are fighting it for a long time already. Dead Island showed the start of infection, lack of knowledge and skills. Dying Light, shows what becomes of such fight in a few months, when it becomes a routine. It reminds me of Metro and S.T.A.L.K.E.R. games in this regard. But then there is a dissonance. Secret agent infiltrating an organization on the matter of (yet?) incomplete cure? Come on, they all need the cure, so any concerns regarding it should be discussed openly, no? And where in real world does a noob prove himself in an organization as if it's an old-school RPG? Overall, if you prefer a post-apocalyptic zombie game with a serious look and can ignore some minor issues with the story and story-telling - you may try this. If the above does not really appeal to you, skip. I am skipping it, because I'm just not in the mood for such seriousness at the moment.

Remember how Dead Island was a dumb frustrating pile a crap that occasionally broke out into a few minutes of fun? Imagine that, but just change nothing. It's a shame because the fun moments are really fun, but so many gameplay choices that were made are just bad. A few examples  - Playing solo and die during a mission after killing 2/4 guys? Meh, there's still only those 2 left, just keep throwing your corpse at the problem until it goes away.   - On that note, death really has no meaning in this game. I set the game to the hardest difficulty because I was hoping for some intense zombie action, but like with Bioshock, it doesn't matter how hard the enemy is, when you get infinite respawns with minimal penalties (only losing Surivor XP, which is incredibly easy to get back) nothing has any threat anymore.  - Playing 'Be the Zombie' for the first time? Enjoy fighting 4 people with auto shotguns! Not sure if this mode ever has more than one zombie player in the match, but if not I have no idea how one would deal with being perma-stunned by 4 shotguns/UV lights  - Zombies are attracted to sound, right? That's why when you shoot a gun, runners will start coming after you. So why is it that if there's an explosion way in the distance, the runners still come after me? Shouldn't they be heading to the big bang a mile away?  *Spoilers* I think the prime example of how the devs didn't things through was the fight against the first Demolisher. Now, I understand that this was supposed to be a tough fight. You've lost your gear, your identity is blown, your ♥♥♥♥ed, and now here's this big ♥♥♥ beast covered in armor that you need to kill. I loved it. Until I died. As usual, I lost an insignificant amount of exp, then respawn. Now here's the problem: the Demolisher's health was restored, which is fine, but the machete, the only weapon worth a damn I have available to me still hasn't had it's durability restored, which is not fine. I had to run around, grab one of the ♥♥♥♥♥ pipes laying around, quickly disassemble it and repair my machete. Playing on the hardest difficulty, it was pretty easy to get one hit by the bugger, and I get that it's my fault for choosing that, but I beat him with probably under 10 hits left on the machete and 0 repairs left, and had I not won then, I'd essentially be getting punished for trying too many times by being forced to use weapons that deal a fifth of the damage of the machete. I could write another paragraph about how dumb the escape sequence was after the pit, but I think my point is across.  All in all, I've had some fun with this game. I enjoy sneaking around shooting arrows at zombies, and if you can get the game cheap or find a friend willing to play it with you, go for it. Other than that, skip it. There are a thousand other shooters out there, and plenty of them are zombie games more worthwhile than Dyling Light.

Is Dying Light a good Zombie game? Yes. Is Dying Light the best zombie game out there? Definitely not.  What you need to understand is before there was Dying Light there was Dead Island, and then the publisher authorizes another studio to make the sequels, which should have been your first clue as to how the original game goes. Now Techland couldn't let such a good zombie IP go so easily, which is why there is Dying Light. Now to be fair, Dying Light is a much better game compare to the original Dead Island. The parkour system is a must for the kind of zombie game Techland is trying to achieve, the story is much better than the original Dead Island game (which isn't saying much because the story of the original is basically nonexistence). but on the other hand still isn't all that well written or paced compared to series like the Dead Rising series. The bad guys isn't as complex (i.e: flat) or memorable like Vaas from Far Cry 3. So in summary, had Dying Light comes out before those aformentioned games then it'll probably be okay, but since all those other game comes out Dying Light will inevitably get compared to those before it and in comparison, Dying Light's parkour system isn't as good as Mirror's Edge. It's story isn't as good as Dead Rising, and the Psycho villain isn't as interesting as Far Cry's villain.  Another thing I wanna complain about is the fact that boss encounter is annoyingly predictable. Every time the game strips you of all your inventory and you'll have to use whatever equipment the game throws at you. Which I find really annoying because if I grind for a powerful sword or something, I wanna get the option to dominate the boss I fight, even if it means the game become less challenging. And I want my game to restore my inentory after I'm done with that segment. In the final boss fight, you don't even get to use your equipment because the last fight was done completely in QTE.   TL;DR: Dying Light is a good game, but not a great zombie game. Don't get it for the full price but maybe for 50% or 75% off.

I liked many aspects of Dying Light, but ultimately, I can't recommend it. I purchased it as a co-op title, having enjoyed Dead Island, despite its many flaws. Dying Light improves upon Dead Island in many ways - the characters are less cartoonish, the zombies more menacing, and the environments diverse and well-crafted.  Unfortunately, some pretty simple flaws in the UI and experience created major headaches. The game relied too much on QTEs and other animated events that broke the flow of gameplay. It required both players to be present in the same location to accept a quest - a silly decision. The final nail in the coffin was that both the beginning and the end of the game can't be played cooperatively. The end of a game should be a crescendo of all that led up to it - and this one fell flat.

To start, I want to say that I like this game, but it is frustratinly average at times. I encourage you to read the entire review and decide for your self if you want to buy it or not.  Let me say that I ♥♥♥♥ing love the parkour. Thats the only thing I really liked in this game. The story is the stupidest thing I have ever played.   They kill off characters that you barely know.   I couldn't care less when they did that. The amount of cheesy lines in this game is beyond ridiculous. I wonder what the budget was like when writing this miserable excuse of a script like 12 dollars? Besides that, I love the parkour, environment, music and combat system. Dying light ACTUALLY makes you want to avoid the zombies from the beginning to the very end. It is a nice change of pace from those typical zombie games where you just slash through the zombies like paper. Speaking of the word zombie, this is the first time in a video game ever that refers to the zombies as zombies. About time, Let's talk in more detail about the game and its aspects so you understand why I am conflicted.   The Story and Sidequests:  The story starts off pretty good, jumping from a jet into a hellhole with a simple task of retrieving a document from a mysterious person. Without giving to much away from the actual storyline I want to talk about the quests themselves and the structure of the storyline. This is not a game you can complete in one sitting. The quests are as follows, Go to point A, across the map then return to point B across the map. It is so tedious to do this over and over again each time. The antagonist is poorly written and executed. This villian reminds me of Vaas from Farcry 3 except not as memorable. In fact not memorable at all. The side quests suffer the same fate, except there is no real reason that you want to complete it. I found myself not wanting to continue the story. It became so dull and so dry in the middle and at the end. It is like they just gave up with making it even remotely fun in the middle. There is one quest that was completely useless.    When you destroy the tower that houses the Volatiles, nothing really happened except Rahim died   . Most of the quests borrow from what I like to call the 'Farcry 3 school of climbing antenna towers'. It uses the ropes hanging from the edge of platforms to hint that you need to climb there to continue going up, just like it did in Farcry 3. This game is also riddled with fetch quests. IT IS SO BORING. I wanted to complete this game 100% but I just couldn't make myself suffer anymore through those tedious quests. I would rather drink a gallon of bleach. They tried to write a good story and at times it was really fun, but too much of it was complete and utter ♥♥♥♥. Luckily this game redeems itself with its combat and parkour systems.  3/10    Combat:  Combat is done perfectly, it is nice to actually be afraid of the zombies for once. I might be the only one but I got tired of playing zombie games that just allow the player to mow down zombies like they are a peice of paper. The zombies in Dying Light are tough and require multiple hits to kill. Early on in the game it is brutually difficult if you have no experience with this type of combat system but you adapt to it pretty quickly. There is weapon degradation which is a cool feature in my opinion. It is nice having weapons break and needing to repair them, but this game takes it a step further. In addition to needing to repair weapons there is only a certain amount of times you can repair a specific item. There are multiple types of zombies, 1. Regular zombie, slow and dumb easy to take down. 2. Virals, the fast mother ♥♥♥♥ers that are attracted to noise and can dodge your attacks and parkour as well. In numbers, these zombies are deadly but one or two are easy to take down. 3. Goons, these zombies have rebars and are very hard to take down in the very beginning of the game. They are introduced in the first 30 minutes of the game. They have rebars as previously explained and can kill other zombies which can be very useful. 4. Spitters, they spit goo that hurts you and is very annoying. 5. The demolishers or what I call the 'Tanks' which they are, they are tanks and are really annoying and strong. They are basically the rammers from Dead Island mixed with the Tank from Left 4 Dead. 6. Bombers, zombies that explode when shot, or near you. 7. Screamers, which let out a loud scream that not only hurts you but attracts multiple virals as well. 8. Volatiles, Oh my god these ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥s are basically immortal. Yes, you CAN kill them, but early on in the game you might as well be attacking a wall. They only come out at night and are faster than you, so you cannot out run them unless you get lucky. I avoid them at all costs.  10/10    Parkour:  The parkour is done perfectly, very few mishapes during the game in the later portions but overall it is beautiful. This game is what Dead Island should have been. There is not a whole lot to say except it is well implemented and explained perfectly in the prologue.  10/10    Characters:  The characters are not memorable. You don't connect to them and do not have enough time to care about them   before the game decides to kill them  . Crane is the average protagonist. Male who has no credibility but is trusted with handling all of the Tower's needs. Oh don't forget that there is an awkward romance side between Jade and Crane. Although it is not directly addressed, it is hinted at multiple times. It would be nice to have a protagonist that does not want to stick his ♥♥♥♥ in the first female character you meet. As cliche as it is, I didn't expect anything new. Rais is horrible, a wannabe Vaas from Farcry 3 as I already stated but done horribly. Most games leave you hating the antagonist while this one makes me want him to shut the ♥♥♥♥ up for ten minutes. He talks consistently and is extremely annoying. While the characters are not horrible, they are just plainly average and there was so much potential to make them memorable and likeable. 5/10    Overall:  I recommend this game to anyone who likes the zombie genre. While I personally am burnt out of the genre I still played this game. I liked it for the most part, don't get me wrong. I just thought the story and characters were painfully average. While some of you will disagree with me which is totally fine, this is just how I felt about the game I still recommend people to buy it. So overall, i give this game a  7/10  Not the absolute best best I ever played but then again not the worst. This game had so much potential and it hurts me to see it fail in some aspects. Not a bad game and I encourage people to buy it if they have time to kill or absolutely love the zombie genre.
